characters: THE PHOTO OF BRAHMS AND THE LITTLE GIRL

dialogues.speaker: THE DRIVER
dialogues.text: Takes notice in his rear-view. He’s an ancient looking guy, more hair coming out of his ears than on his head. He works his mirror back and forth with vulgar fervor, trying to get just the right view down her shirt. He’s almost there when-- Gerti shifts again, her shirt closing. The Driver turns his full attention back to the road dejectedly.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Shite...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car’s stopped. The driver circles the car to the back seat where Gerti is still curled up, asleep. He gives a light knock. No response. Gives it another, less polite, knock. Nothing. Mumbles a curse to himself. Opens the car door...

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Miss? We’ve arrived, Miss. Gerti doesn’t even move. She’s out. The Driver let’s out a “I don’t get paid enough for this” sigh. Gently taps her shoulder. Gerti turns slightly and lets out another snore. Finally the Driver gives her a good nudge. Gerti bolts awake. Grabs his hand, ready to defend herself. The old Driver just about has a heart attack--

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: I apologize, Miss, I was-- Gerti looks around sleepily, not yet sure where she is or what she’s doing.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Uh, we’re here, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Sorry, I was dreaming. Mustering his best British politeness--—

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Not at all, Miss. Perfectly alright. Gerti steps out of the car and into the shadow of

dialogues.speaker: HEELSHIRE MANOR
dialogues.text: An old, two-story building with large barred windows that almost give the impression of lifeless eyes peering out from behind large, leafy trees. Gerti shudders - maybe because of the cold.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: It’s like something out of a book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it’s very lovely. I’ve taken your things inside. He pulls a letter from his pocket and hands it to Gerti--

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: From the Heelshires. Gerti unfolds it revealing long, flowing, beautiful hand- writing. Before she can read it--

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: They’ve stepped out. They beg your pardon, Miss, and ask that you wait in the parlour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerti pops a piece of gum in her mouth and looks around, surveying her surroundings, says what we’re thinking:

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Holy crap. The entrance-way is cavernous, reaching up to the second floor. The house itself is old-time, solid construction. Thick, wood beams run up the walls. Gerti walks timidly to the right and pokes her head into-

dialogues.speaker: THE LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: The first thing you notice is there are no windows on one side. In fact, as we'll find out, there are no windows on the entire back-side of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next thing is the furniture. Dusty antiques, all of it. The living room time forgot. A GRANDFATHER CLOCK sits in the corner. It’s stopped at 6:30 and, from the looks of it, it’s been stopped there a long, long time. Gerti peaks out of the front window, surveys the front yard through thick, steel bars. And then she walks back through the entranceway to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More of the same. That eerie lack of windows. An ornately carved dining table with a few rickety looking wooden chairs around it.

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCEWAY
dialogues.text: Gerti pulls out the letter again, trying carefully not to make too much noise as she unfolds it. There’s a heavy silence in the house. A formal gloom that Gerti unconsciously is scared to break--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: (reading) .-..we ask that you wait in the parlour... Gerti looks around--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Which one is the parlour? And then she looks at--

dialogues.speaker: THE STAIRS
dialogues.text: Directly in front of her - a wooden railing almost looks like it’s reaching out a deformed, wooden hand to her-- The staircase splits in two midway up - and where it splits is a large painting of the house’s residents - THE HEELSHIRES. It’s not the parlour, but...

dialogues.speaker: CREAK
dialogues.text: Gerti takes a step on the stairs, breaking the heavy silence of the house. She takes another, softer step - willing herself to be lighter. A slightly quieter CREAK up to...

dialogues.speaker: THE PAINTING
dialogues.text: The PARENTS, Mr. and Mrs. Heelshire, each have a hand on their young son’s shoulders. The FATHER is tall, dignified looking. The MOTHER is small, squat and stern. An odd-looking pair. The SON looks to be around seven. He’s almost disturbingly perfect looking in a dated looking little suit.  He has perfectly combed hair, perfect skin with perfect features and a slight, half-smile as if he knows something we don’t. But the eyes are what sticks out - black and huge and lifeless. The right eye has a slight rip in the canvas. Gerti reaches out to touch it when-- A CREAK. The house settling or maybe a CHILD’S FOOTSTEPS from the floor above.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Hello? Gerti looks up the stairs to the second floor.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: (to herself) That’s not the parlour. That is definitely not the parlour. Gerti looks back down the stairs where she should go - and then looks up again--

dialogues.speaker: SECOND FLOOR
dialogues.text: CLUNK, CLUNK. The sound of high-heels on a wood floor, shattering the silence of the house. Gerti slips off her shoes and places them carefully against the wall. She tip-toes barefoot down the hallways. They’re narrow. Claustrophobic. As if the walls were pressing inward. More portraits. Various other family members going back through the years. Each staring out silently as Gerti passes down to--

dialogues.speaker: A BOY'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Unlike the rest of the house this room looks untouched, pristine. A child’s bed perfectly made. A few toys on shelves. It looks more like a show room than an actual child’s room. A DOOR SHUTS somewhere in the house. Gerti quickly tip-toes out of the room and down the hall, right past her shoes without noticing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Hello? She moves down the stairs towards the voice--

dialogues.speaker: A MAN'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Yes? Hello? Back through the Entranceway to--

dialogues.speaker: THE DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: At the other end is the owner of the voice, MALCOLM (30's). He’s smack dab between handsome and nerdy - and very English looking. He’s dressed in a black tie and a white shirt, making him look like an off duty waiter.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Hello. A beat. Malcolm seems a little bit shocked to see this pretty girl standing before him.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: You're the new nanny?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I’m not sure yet. Mr. Heelshire?

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Me? No, I’m the grocery boy. Grocery man. I deliver groceries. I own the store actually. (flustered) I saw your bags and I...I’m Malcolm by the way. He puts out his hand to Gerti. The two shake awkwardly--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Gerti Evans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’ve got to unpack these groceries, care to join me? I can give you a tour of such exotic locations as the pantry and the bread cupboard. Gerti smiles--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Lead the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large kitchen - the kind that probably once housed a whole staff of servants. Now it’s just Malcolm and Gerti stuffing cans of food on shelves--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: American, yeah?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Yeah. My first trip out of the country.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Let me guess...California, right? Gerti looks at him, not sure if he’s joking or not. She’s got a pretty unmistakable Texan accent.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Texas

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Hm. I’m usually so good at these things. I’ve got a touch of the gift you know.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: The gift?

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Prognosticator. Clairvoyant. Whatever you like to call it. I had a grandmum that read tea-leaves. My mother read palms.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: And what do you read? Malcolm looks at her, thinking. Gerti chews her gum--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Chewing gum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gum?

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: If you'll allow me... Malcolm holds out his hand. Gerti stops chewing. Is this guy serious?

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Don’t be shy. Gerti spits her gum into Malcolm’s hand. Off Gerti’s somewhat disgusted look--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: We don’t get to choose our gifts, Miss Evans. Malcolm examines the gum carefully. He turns it over in his hand, squints his eyes in concentration.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: So what do you see?

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Interesting. Very, very interesting. I see that you're a writer...from Dallas, Texas. It looks like you’ve come here to be inspired by the English countryside. To get away from the hustle and bustle of your life in the U.S. of A. Gerti LAUGHS. Not even close.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Close?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Not even a little. Malcolm looks back at the gum.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Rubbish. One more try, yeah? Okay...ah! Here it is. I see what went wrong. Ah, a dark past. On the run are we?  He smiles. Gerti doesn’t. That one hit a little too close to home.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Sorry. I’m afraid that was my best attempt at flirting. Believe it or not I'm actually considered charming here in this country. It’s amazing that any of us manage to procreate at all really. Gerti grabs a loaf of bread.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Bread? Malcolm clears his throat uncomfortably. Tough crowd.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Cupboard behind you.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: So what's the family like?

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: The family? Well...they’re nice. Very generous. As good a people as you'll ever hope to meet. Gerti hands Malcolm some cans--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: And their son. Brahms?

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Brahms. Yes. He’s...uh...I’m not sure how to put it... Malcolm searches for the words as A DOOR OPENS in another room. Saved by the bell--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: --here they are now. That’s all he can say as MRS. HEELSHIRE enters the kitchen. If we thought the artist was taking some liberties in the painting of the woman we were very, very wrong. Mrs. Heelshire is short and squat - not quite a little person, but definitely less than average height. She looks as if she stepped directly out of the painting.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: Miss Evans?  10.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Mrs. Heelshire, it’s so nice to finally meet you.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: Yes. Follow me, Miss Evans.

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE WAY
dialogues.text: We can hear talk in the other room. It’s serious,

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: Brahms is very excited to meet you, Miss Evans. He’s never met an American before.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I'm very excited to meet him too. I’ve never met an English person. Well, I mean, I met Malcolm and you, but-- Mrs. Heelshire stops. She looks at Gerti’s feet.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: Where are your shoes? Gerti looks down at her shoe-less feet. She looks up at Mrs. Heelshire, embarrassed. SECOND FLOOR —- HALLWAY Mrs. Heelshire waits, arms folded, in the hallway. Gerti comes out of a room with an apologetic look on her face.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I was sure I took them off right here.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: They'll turn up. It’s Brahms. He can be...playful. I assume you brought other shoes? Gerti gives one last glance around--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: In my bag.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: Good. Now come along, we’ve kept them waiting long enough.  11.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: MR. HEELSHIRE, is bent down on his knee, obscuring the figure he’s talking to, presumably Brahms. Mrs. Heelshire clears her throat. Mr. Heelshire stands obediently and turns toward Gerti. He, like Mrs. Heelshire, looks like he stepped directly out of the painting. And then we get our first look at the figure Mr. Heelshire was talking to... A DOLL. Literally. A life-size and somewhat life-like doll with a perfect porcelain face, not unlike the painting, with perfect, delicate hands and wearing a suit like you might see British children wear in the 1950’s. It, or he, as this is BRAHMS, stands facing Gerti--

dialogues.speaker: MR. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: Miss Evans, allow me to introduce you to our son, Brahms. A beat. A long, painful, silent beat where Gerti opens her mouth, then closes it unable to find the proper words for a situation like this. Finally, Gerti manages to make a sound. She LAUGHS. An uncomfortable, unsure laugh. The kind of forced chuckle you give when you’re not quite sure if someone is joking. The whole thing would be funny if it weren’t so creepy. Mr. and Mrs. Heelshire give each other a disappointed, meaningful look. Gerti notices it, but all she can do is let out another little NERVOUS LAUGH. Gerti’s drowning. She looks at Mr. Heelshire, then Mrs. Heelshire - and then tries again to try and say something. Her mouth opens and closes. Malcolm swoops in just in time--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: You’ve met Brahms then?  12. Without missing a beat Malcolm gets down on a knee and shakes Brahms’s porcelain hand, careful to look and talk directly to him, as if he was a real little boy.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: How are you doing, Brahms? You take it easy on Miss Evans, she’s traveled a long way just to meet you. Malcolm stands up-

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I’m off then. Bill’s on the table. (to Gerti) Pleasure meeting you, Miss Evans. Hope to see you when I deliver next Thursday. He smiles at Gerti. Gerti’s face says it all - THANK YOU!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Malcolm. Gerti regains herself. She kneels down to Brahms level, just like Malcolm did, and takes Brahms’ little porcelain hand in hers.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: It’s so nice to meet you, Brahms. I hope you and I can be friends. Mrs. Heelshire smiles broadly at Mr. Heelshire. Gerti’s passed the first test. And now on to the other tests--

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: Mr. Heelshire, will you please take Miss Evans’ things to her room? Miss Evans, we might as well get started. I have quite a bit to show you. If you’ll help Brahms along, we'll begin upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: STAIRS
dialogues.text: Mrs. Heelshire moves up the stairs with surprising quickness for a woman of her age and size. Behind her Gerti struggles, huffing and puffing, with Brahms held awkwardly in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: Brahms has a detailed schedule. You are detail oriented, aren’t you?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Yes...detail...oriented.  13.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: We'll run through a typical day. It’s Brahms’ decision in the end and he can be quite selective. We’ve had a number of nannies come through already. Though none of them were nearly as pretty or as young as you. Mrs. Heelshire turns around. Looks at Gerti.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: That is your real hair color, I assume? Gerti reaches up, touches her blonde hair--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah. It is.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: That’s good. You never know nowadays. Mrs. Heelshire continues up the stairs. Gerti stands there for a beat wondering what, exactly, she’s gotten herself in9to... UPSTAIRS - BRAHMS ROOM -— CONTINUOUS Mrs. Heelshire undresses Brahms and then puts little doll pajamas on him as she talks.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: You'll wake him at 7:00 each morning and dress him. Mrs. Heelshire finishes putting Brahms in pajamas and puts him in bed. Then she looks at Gerti expectantly. Gerti stands there, not quite sure what she’s supposed to do. Mrs. Heelshire motions toward a dresser.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: You'll find his clothes in there.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: So I should...?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: Wake and dress him, Miss Evans. There’s no better way to learn than by doing. Gerti walks to the dresser and opens up the top drawer. Inside are five full outfits; socks, underwear, pants, shirt and jacket. She pulls one out and walks to the bed where Brahms is “sleeping”.  14. Gerti stands over Brahms, still not sure what to do. She gives a glance toward Mrs. Heelshire. Mrs. Heelshire nods, as if to say, “yes, keep going...”

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Um...wake up...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: I don’t know about you, but that certainly wouldn’t wake me. Gerti takes a breath - okay, fine. Gerti sits on the bed next to Brahms.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: It's time to wake up, Brahms. She pulls the covers off of him and pulls him up into her arms very gently and carefully. Then, just as slowly and carefully, she begins to pull off his pajamas. At the rate Gerti is going Brahms will be fully dressed and ready to go in about 3 hours.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: He’s not a newborn, Miss Evans. You needn't worry about hurting him. Mrs. Heelshire walks over and practically pushes Gerti out of the way and starts dressing him, quickly, efficiently and, not coincidentally, like a woman who has done this for decades... To Brahms, in the way you’d speak to your real child--

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: Now let’s show Miss Evans how to get you dressed. I’d let her do it, but I’m afraid we’d be here all afternoon, wouldn’t we? HALLWAY — CONTINUOUS Mrs. Heelshire moves along briskly with Gerti walking behind her lugging Brahms...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: Normally breakfast would be next, but it’s already the afternoon now, so we'll move on to class. Brahms, as you might imagine, is home-schooled.  15. Mrs. Heelshire comes to a door at the end of the hall and stops. She looks at Gerti who stands there with Brahms, breathing heavy - it’s not a light doll.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: He can be a bit much to carry, I’m afraid. I’ve got Mr. Heelshire to help me, but you’ll be alone out here. Do you think you can manage?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: (out of breath) Of course. No problem. Mrs. Heelshire seems doubtful.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: You're awfully skinny. But then people have doubted me my whole life and I manage. Mrs. Heelshire opens the door to--

dialogues.speaker: THE CLASSROOM
dialogues.text: The walls are lined with bookcases full of dusty books. In the center of the room are two desks and at the front a podium. All very mid-50's style.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: Brahms has three hours of class five days a week. I like to begin by reading some poetry. Do you know any poetry, Miss Evans.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Not really. I do know all the words to “Sweet Home Alabama” though. A beat. Mrs. Heelshire just stares at Gerti, the kind of stare reserved for blathering idiots--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: It was a kind of a joke...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: We have plenty of books. Choose one and then read through it. (demonstrating) It's very important you speak in a LOUD, CLEAR VOICE. As politely as she can muster--  16.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Yes. Of course. Mrs. Heelshire looks at her blankly - waiting. A beat. Then Gerti realizes and replies in a CLEAR, LOUD, VOICE.

dialogues.speaker: YES. OF COURSE.
dialogues.text: Mrs. Heelshire smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: Excellent. Then she spins on her heels and vanishes back out into the hallway--

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Music appreciation is next... Gerti rolls her eyes and shifts Brahms in her arms. What has she gotten herself into?

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Brahms sits on the couch. He starts to slide, then falls over onto his side. Mrs. Heelshire is there in an instant, setting him upright again.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: Now be a good boy, Brahms, and sit up. Mrs. Heelshire motions toward a large cabinet style record player almost buried underneath stacks of records.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: Music, Miss Evans. I don’t think Brahms could go on without his music. It means everything to him. It is his world. She picks up a record and sets it on the turntable--

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: You simply take a record and place it here, then take the needle and... The record starts spinning. From the hum and hiss we can tell the volume is turned up LOUD--

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: Brahms likes it a bit louder than I prefer, but it gives him so much joy I don’t dare take it away from him.  17. Right on cue, the music jumps in - a THUNDEROUS BURST that nearly gives Gerti a heart-attack. Mrs. Heelshire closes her eyes, enjoying the music. Gerti looks at Brahms and it almost - almost - looks as if a little smile has crept onto his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Heelshire circles the table. A bowl of some kind of steaming stew for Mr. Heelshire, Gerti and then finally, for Brahms. Mr. Heelshire ties a napkin around Brahms’s neck before she sits. Gerti can’t take her eyes off the whole sad/creepy affair. Mr. Heelshire clears his throat loudly--

dialogues.speaker: MR. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: Brahms is very fond of your accent. He says it makes you sound like a movie star. Gerti laughs and blushes despite herself.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: You think so? Mr. Heelshire gives a slight motion with his head for Gerti to speak directly to Brahms. Gerti turns toward Brahms--—

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I think the English accent is so much nicer.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: Brahms would like to know if you’ve ever been horse riding? Or met any Indians? Gerti has the hang of it now - she turns to Brahms as if he was a real little boy--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I've been on a horse. I think everyone in Texas has. As for, uh, Native Americans - well, I’ve only seen them in casinos. Mr. and Mrs. Heelshire smile at one another. Maybe this will work out after all...  18.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Mrs. Heelshire walks quickly into the kitchen - she’s back in tour mode, going a mile-a-minute. Gerti follows her lugging the dinner dishes.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: We don’t throw any food out in this house, Miss Evans. This is a country house, do you know what that means? On Gerti - um...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: It means we are in a constant battle with the outside elements. Weather and plants and vermin. Especially vermin, Miss Evans. So we take certain measures against them. She opens a cupboard - inside is a mountain of tupperware. Mrs. Heelshire takes Brahms’s bowl of stew and dumps it in a container.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: Mr. Heelshire can tell you about those duties. For the first time Gerti notices Mr. Heelshire standing in the doorway holding Brahms lovingly in his arms. He hands Brahms to Mrs. Heelshire and takes the tupperware.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: If you'll follow me...

dialogues.speaker: LAUNDRY ROOM
dialogues.text: A large freezer is shoved into the corner of the room. Mr. Heelshire drops the tupperware container inside.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: The food goes in here. Now I’1l show you the traps. On Gerti: Traps?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerti, holding a large garbage bag, waits by the side of the house. Mr. Heelshire emerges from behind a shrub with a large rat-trap containing one very large, very dead rat.  19. He pulls the rat out of the trap as he talks--

dialogues.speaker: MR. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: Personally, I don’t know that any of this is necessary. But the Missus is convinced they’1l get into the walls. And Brahms... Mr. Heelshire drops the rat into the bag and resets the trap. Gerti looks like she might drop the bag and run away any second--

dialogues.speaker: MR. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: ..-well, Brahms has never been very fond of animals of any kind. He was always very shy, you see. Very timid. Mr. Heelshire’s voice drops, almost to a whisper, as if he doesn’t want the house itself to hear him--

dialogues.speaker: MR. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: I know how it must look to you, Miss Evans. To be completely honest I’m not sure how it all came to this. Little by little and then all at once, I suppose. Mr. Heelshire bends behind another shrub. Gerti grimaces, not sure if she can stand another bloody rat corpse.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: Empty. They move on to the next trap.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: What I’m trying to say, Miss, is that whatever it might look like on the outside, our son is here. He’s very much with us. Do you understand, Miss Evans?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Yes. Mr. Heelshire smiles--

dialogues.speaker: MR. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: Good. That’s very good. They reach the end of the house where a large chimney rises up along the house. A thick shrub grows around it--  20.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: No need to look here. We don’t put traps ‘round the chimney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bath water runs... Brahms sits in the tub. His little suit is hung up on the shower rod. His doll-body is a yellowed kind of fabric with patches and repairs here and there. From the looks of it this is an old doll. Gerti stands in the doorway and watches as Mrs. Heelshire gently, lovingly cleans his hands and face with a wet cloth. The whole time she talks to him, just as you would a real child.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: You were a very good boy today, Brahms. I’m very proud of you. You behaved like a little gentleman... She combs his fake hair carefully. A clump falls out--

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: Oh dear. We’1ll have to get papa to fix this...

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Brahms is in bed. Mr. and Mrs. Heelshire are on either side of him, hands folded, heads bowed in prayer. Gerti waits in the doorway, not daring to break up this strangely touching family moment. The prayer ends. Mr. Heelshire whispers something to his wife and they both turn toward Gerti. Gerti’s heart skips a beat - though she’s not even sure what she’s afraid of.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: If you would give us one second to speak with Brahms... Gerti backs out of the room, into the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Heelshire closes the door. Gerti shivers. A cold night in a drafty house. LOW, URGENT VOICES from inside the room. Gerti strains to hear. For a second it almost sounds as if a CHILD'S VOICE is among them. The door opens--

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: He wants you, Miss Evans. He’s chosen you if you’ll have him. She hugs Gerti. The look on Gerti’s face is neither excitement or dismay, it’s the same face she’s had all day - overwhelmed. INT. GERTI’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Gerti’s bags are spread across the floor. Gerti steps over them, pacing and talking on the phone to her older sister, SANDY.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I didn’t do anything. I couldn’t even speak. If the grocery boy - er, man - hadn't come by I'd probably still be standing there. LAUGHTER on the other end of the line--

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: So...are you going to do it? Gerti sighs--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I don’t know. The whole thing is just creepy. This house. The doll--

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: --the money. You’ll make more in three months than I make in a year. That kind of money can change your life, Gert.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I feel guilty. I mean these people are seriously nuts. I shouldn’t take advantage of them. You should have seen the way they treated it. Like a real little kid. It’s heartbreaking.  22.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: If it makes them happy, who cares? Play along. We talked about this. This is good for you. You need to get away for a while. Get some perspective.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: So living with a doll all summer is perspective?

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Yes. Coming from what you came from, it is. You need this.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I don’t know. This house. The doll. These sad, sad people. It’s just...it’s too weird. A beat, the kind always followed by bad news--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Cole's been asking about you. He’s been calling non-stop. He came by the house and scared Morgan half-to-death. Looking like she got kicked in the gut--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: What’d you tell him?

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Nothing. And I’m not going to tell him anything. (a heavy beat) You have to get away from him, Gert. Do this. If not for you, then for me. I can’t stand to see you get hurt again. Gerti takes a breath like a woman about to take the plunge...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stack of ancient looking luggage. The kind of stuff you’d expect to see getting loaded onto the Titanic. The Driver that dropped Gerti off is back. He picks up two of the larger suitcases and carries them--  23.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: Where the car is waiting. The trunk open. He tries to toss both suitcases in the back at once. One falls to the ground--

dialogues.speaker: THE DRIVER
dialogues.text: Bloody... The Driver stops. Looks at the suitcase. Empty. Not a single item in there. He looks back at the house. Picks up the suitcase. Closes it back up.

dialogues.speaker: THE DRIVER
dialogues.text: Crazy old buggers. Stuffs it into the trunk of the car and trudges back to the house...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerti walks out of her room. The SOUNDS OF PLEADING. An urging, whispering voice coming from Brahms’ room. Gerti tip-toes to his room and peaks--

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: Brahms is set up on the side of the bed, like a real little boy listening to his mother. Mrs. Heelshire stands at the foot of the bed with her back to the doll. By the sound of her voice she’s on the verge of tears--

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: ..-had to happen. It’s time now and we have to go and you’ve got to be a good boy, Brahms. You promised us--

dialogues.speaker: MR. HEELSHIRE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I apologize for the rush, Miss Evans. Gerti whips around. Mr. Heelshire stands over her ina black suit, looking like death going on a holiday. He walks toward the stairs, motions for Gerti to follow--

dialogues.speaker: MR. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: It's been many years now since we've had a holiday and we’re anxious to be off. Besides Brahms seems to be so fond of you and in this matter his opinion is of the highest importance. I only wish we could have shown you some of the... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: MR. HEELSHIRE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: idiosyncracies of life with a child as unique as our Brahms. But you’ll figure them out, I suppose. I have some things to help you along. (pulling out papers) A schedule. Mrs. Heelshire took the effort to write one down for each day. Again that impossibly perfect handwriting like something out of the 19th century. Time’s listed from 7:00 A.M. until midnight. From washing cheeks to reading stories - every hour full of something for Brahms. Mr. Heelshire hands her another paper. At the top is written “RULES” under which is a set of rules listed 1 through 10. We note some of them: NEVER LEAVE BRAHMS ALONE, NO GUESTS and GOODNIGHT KISS EVERY NIGHT. Mr. Heelshire almost looks embarrassed as he hands them to Gerti--

dialogues.speaker: MR. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: Rules might seem a bit silly, but it’s important that you follow them, Miss. Brahms isn’t like other children and he can be...particular. I’m afraid we might have indulged him a bit over the years.

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE-WAY
dialogues.text: Mr. Heelshire stops - looks as if he’s going to cry. He reaches out and puts a large hand on Gertie’s shoulder, then gives it a pat, as you would a soldier about to storm the beach at Normandy.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: I'm a bit off today. It’s been so long since we’ve gone anywhere. The Driver comes in--

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: All ready then.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: (calling up the stairs) It’s time, mother. Mrs. Heelshire appears, holding Brahms in her arms. Tears on her cheeks as she slowly descends the stairs. One painful step at a time - a kind of sad and bizarre descent to the entrance-way.  25. She kisses Brahms porcelain face one last time and hands him to Mr. Heelshire. Mrs. Heelshire grabs Gerti tightly in her arms and whispers into her ear--

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Gerti stands there - accepting the hug with a bewildered hug of her own until Mr. Heelshire leads Mrs. Heelshire towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: Come on, dear, it’s time we left. Mr. Heelshire hands Brahms to Gerti.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: Be good to him and he’1l be good to you. Be bad to him and...well, be good to him, won't you Miss Evans? Mustering a smile--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Of course. I’11 treat him like my own. Now go and enjoy your vacation. You have nothing to worry about here. All Mr. Heelshire can muster is a weak nod. He closes the door behind him. The house is suddenly very silent, very big and very empty. Gerti waits - listening, until-- The sound of the CAR DRIVING AWAY. She let’s out a BIG BREATH - like she’s been holding it since she arrived. She heads to the couch and sets Brahms down. He stares back at her, that strange little painted smile on his face. Those black, dead eyes. A beat. Finally, Gerti can’t stand it anymore. She picks up a blanket and tosses it over Brahms.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: No offense, but you creep me out.  26. INT. GERTI’S ROOM - DAY Chaotic unpacking. Clothes and magazines everywhere. Gerti grabs an armful of shirts, jeans and socks out of her suitcase and crams them into a drawer. She turns back to the suitcase and sees

dialogues.speaker: A WELL-WORN PICTURE
dialogues.text: It's her, a bit younger, and a MAN holding hands and smiling at the camera. We don’t know it yet, but this is COLE, the man that Gerti’s sister mentioned. Gerti takes the picture and shoves it in a drawer underneath a heap of underwear and socks.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Some British comedy flickers on the TV. Gerti eats a PB & J and drinks a glass of wine - the dinner of champions. She takes a quick, almost guilty glance at Brahms, still covered in the blanket, still sitting on the chair where she left him. A LAUGH TRACK on the TV pulls her attention back to the show. Gerti giggles along and pours herself another glass of wine... GERTI’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Time for bed. Gerti, in pajamas, crawls into bed and then reaches over and flicks off her lamp. A beat. The room is almost completely back. And then we hear Gerti stirring. The lamp flicks back on and Gerti gets out of the bed and heads to--

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: She pulls the blanket off Brahms. Picks him up. BRAHMS’ ROOM Gerti tosses Brahms on to the bed. Brahms lays there, his limbs akimbo, looking like a broken toy.  27. Gerti pauses, mulling something over. Finally she walks back over to Brahms and lays him out flat. Puts his hands on his chest like a corpse, thinks better of it and then puts them at his side. Finally satisfied she flicks off the light and walks out of the room. We hold on Brahms. A beat. Then another. We’re waiting for something, maybe waiting for him to move, to stand up and follow Gerti out of the room... Outside RAIN starts to fall, building from a few gentle beats to a DULL ROAR that carries over to... GERTI’S ROOM - MORNING Gerti stirs and then opens her eyes. Lifts her head just enough to look around the room - as if she’s remembering where she is-- Gerti lets her head fall back onto the pillow, ready to go back to sleep when she hears something that makes her sit back up. A CHILD CRYING. Big painful SOBS that are just barely audible above the rain outside. Gerti throws the covers off--

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Gerti steps out into the hallway and pauses - listening. MORE CRYING, even louder now. She follows the sound to--

dialogues.speaker: THE STAIRS
dialogues.text: Tiptoes quickly down the stairs, closer and closer to the sounds of the crying child until she reaches--

dialogues.speaker: THE FAMILY PORTRAIT
dialogues.text: The crying stops. Gerti looks around. The house is completely still and silent, save for the ever growing rumble of the rain outside. She studies the painting of the Heelshire family. Something seems different. The rip is missing and Brahms looks almost life-like now. There’s color in his skin and his eyes look as though they might blink any second.  28. Gerti can’t help but reach out towards the painting, towards Brahms’ life-like cheek. The sound of the rain becomes a ROAR, until it’s almost deafening. Gerti is about to touch Brahms’ cheek when--

dialogues.speaker: WOOSH
dialogues.text: Brahms reaches out of the painting! Grabs Gerti. His eyes go black. His skin goes white as porcelain. Gerti SCREAMS! Tries to jerk away, but Brahms hangs on, pulling her into the painting, her own skin going porcelain white, her eyes going completely black as we--

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: GERTI’S BEDROOM - MORNING Gerti wakes up in bed, still SCREAMING and fighting off some invisible foe until she realizes-- It was a dream. Just a dream. She looks around the room, breathing hard as the memory gives way to reality. The sound of rain coming down--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Jesus... Then something that makes her BLOOD RUN COLD. The sound of CRYING. Soft sobs, barely audible above the wind and rain outside. Gerti freezes and listens. A beat. Maybe it was nothing. And then... More CRYING. Gerti throws the covers off--

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Just like in her dream Gerti stops and listens. But the sobs are gone now, replaced by the thousand tiny drumbeats of the rain. Gerti looks towards Brahms’ room and, almost against her will, walks toward it--  29. BRAHMS’ ROOM Brahms is just as she left him. But now something glistens on his cheeks. Gerti moves in closer. The floor CREAKS mercilessly with every step. Gerti bends down, her face close to Brahms. The rain RUMBLING outside.

dialogues.speaker: TEARS
dialogues.text: Running down Brahms’s cheeks. Gerti reaches out and touches his cheek as one of the tears runs down his porcelain face. As soon as she touches it - feels its wetness - she sucks in a breath, making a sound somewhere in between surprise and a stifled scream--

dialogues.speaker: A DROP OF WATER
dialogues.text: falls with a SPLAT on Brahms’ face. Gerti looks up

dialogues.speaker: ON THE CEILING
dialogues.text: A large brown stain from water damage. A drip of water hanging, close to falling and then - DRIP - another drop splashes down on Brahms. Gerti lets out a big sigh of relief--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Come on, Gert. Your first week and you’re already cracking up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rat makes its way along the outside of the house. It stops, sniffs at something and moves on to--

dialogues.speaker: A RAT TRAP
dialogues.text: The rat circles the bait, sniffing. Then, quickly, moves in and--

dialogues.speaker: SNAP
dialogues.text: The trap snaps down on the rat. A SQUEAL. The rat struggles and then goes silent. Dead...  30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerti flips through the channels. News reports. Comedies. Commercials. She keeps flipping until, finally, she just turns it off. Gerti looks around, completely bored and restless - looking for some new way to distract herself... INT. MR. AND MRS. HEELSHIRE’S ROOM - DAY Gerti tip-toes into their room, as if someone might catch her snooping. Goes to the dresser. Opens it slowly, quietly. Full of underwear. Opens another. Full of shirts. The next one. Pants. If these people took anything, it doesn’t look like it. Next to the dresser is a LONG POLE with a hook on the end of it. Gerti holds it, not sure what to make of it. Puts it down again. She goes to the night stand by the bed. Picks up an old looking PICTURE FRAME. The kind that might hold a family photo, but this one is empty.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Well, at least that’s not weird at all. Opens the drawer in the night stand. Just one thing. AN ENVELOPE. It’s unsealed. A beat. Gerti looks around the room. Not sure if she should open it. She pokes a finger in the envelope, pulls out the contents a little. “LAST WILL AND TESTAMENT” written at the top-- A FLASH of something - or someone - passes by in the hallway. Gerti looks up, a second too late. But she feels it - a shiver passes through her. She looks back down at the will. Not exactly the kind of snooping she was hoping for. Stuffs it back in the envelope...

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Gerti heads toward her room when, for some reason, she looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The type in the ceiling that you pull down. She backtracks to the Heelshire’s room. Re-appears with the hooked-pole. She hooks the ring on the door and pulls. It doesn’t budge. She rests for a beat, then really tugs on it. This thing isn’t moving. She gives up. Tosses the hook into Brahms’ room and walks back into her own room.

dialogues.speaker: BATHROOM
dialogues.text: A bubble bath. Gerti reads a magazine. Turns the water on with her toes for a second and then turns it off. She hums some poppy- sounding song and turns the page as... THE SOUND OF A PHONE RINGING on the other side of the line carries over to... INT. GERTI’S ROOM - NIGHT Gerti’s buried under the covers, only her head sticking out, the phone stuck to her ear. The other line rings and rings and no one picks up. Finally her sister’s voice-mail kicks in:

dialogues.speaker: SANDY, (VOICE MAIL)
dialogues.text: Hey ya’all, this is Sandra. Leave a message...or don’t. Beep.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Sandra, it’s me again. I don’t know what time it is. I still haven't figured out the whole time difference thing. Maybe you're asleep. Maybe you’re at work... She pauses, thinking of what to say next--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Call me. Soon. I’m lonely. And this house is creepy. And send more magazines. I’ve read all mine. Especially any with Ryan Gosling. A beat. Gerti doesn’t want to get off the phone--  32.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I want to come home, Sandy. And then she hangs up. Gerti stares at the phone for a beat. She picks it up quickly and dials. It rings and then a MAN’S VOICE answers.

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Hello? Hello? Gerti doesn’t say a word.

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Who is this? A beat. Then the voice changes, becomes softer, more intimate. The way you might speak to a girlfriend--

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Gerti? Is that you? If this is you I just want to say I-- Gerti practically slams the phone down - rushing to hang- up before the Man gets another word out. She stares at the phone for a beat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another gray English day. Heavy clouds stacked along the horizon. The next storm on its way. Gerti walks down the long gravel drive-way to the

dialogues.speaker: MAILBOX
dialogues.text: Flips it open, peers inside. EMPTY. Disappointed, she flips it closed and starts the long trudge back to the lonely cottage when--

dialogues.speaker: A TRUCK
dialogues.text: Turns down the driveway and pulls up along side her. Malcolm rolls down the window, smiles:

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Need a lift?  33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerti puts groceries away, mostly canned goods. Malcolm is just around the corner, pulling the tupperware containers out of the freezer and putting them into a trash bag. Gerti peaks around the corner at him before stuffing yet another can of food in the pantry--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I was wondering about that freezer.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Mrs. Heelshire’s orders. Everything gets thrown out every two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: So all that food just goes to waste? Malcolm holds up an empty tupperware container--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Not all of it. Mr. Heelshire eats a few of them. He’s always been the less strict one about all of this.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: You could have warned me, you know.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: And ruin the surprise?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: How are the two of you getting along? Gerti holds up a jar of peanut butter and a jar of jelly before shoving them into the cupboard--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Like peanut butter and jelly. (beat) So, I have to ask-- Malcolm comes around the corner with his garbage bag of tupperware.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Yes, I am single. Believe it or not. Off Gerti’s look--  34.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: What’s up with the doll?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Not the happiest story, I’m afraid. They had a real son once. A real Brahms. He died as a child. They moved here not long after and built this house. They never went out much - maybe because of the looks they got when they went into town with this doll. And the last few years - I’m not sure they left the house at all. It’s all harmless, though, this little world they’ve made. A way to cope. I can’t imagine how difficult it must be to lose a child.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: How long ago did Brahms - the real Brahms - die?

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: He'd be older than me now, I suppose. 30 or so years ago?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: They've lived like this for 30 years? Malcolm nods--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: And they've been looking for a nanny for the last seven. You must be a special lady, Gertrude Evans. Gerti smiles - something about the way he says her name. She looks at him, really looks at him for the first time. Not a bad looking guy--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Nobody calls me Gertrude. Malcolm smiles - sees his chance.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: You're probably going mad in this house, yeah? It might be good to get out. I could take you to town, if you’d like. Show you the world-famous Norwich nightlife.  35.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I just got out of a...a thing.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Well, this is not a thing. I can assure you of that. This is a professional courtesy seeing as we’re employed by the same people. It’s a duty is what it is. I‘1ll take no pleasure in it whatsoever, I promise. Gerti LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Yeah. INT. BRAHM’S ROOM - NIGHT Light spills in from the hallway. On the bed is a pot filled with water from the leak. The rain has let up, but the leak continues. DRIP. DRIP. Pushed unceremoniously aside is Brahms, turned on his side so he’s facing toward us. In the shadows of the room his knowing smile has taken on a sort of demonic air. We can hear Gerti in the next room TALKING ON THE PHONE. She laughs, walks across the room with light, happy steps, as we-- Begin to pull slowly - almost carefully - out of the room, leaving Brahms alone. He continues to stare at us - through us - with those eyes that suddenly seem almost alive while the smile on his face becomes more and more menacing... INT. GERTI’S ROOM - NIGHT Gerti braces the phone between her cheek and shoulder, then zips up the back of a sexy black dress.  36.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Is it a date?

dialogues.speaker: LOOKING IN THE MIRROR
dialogues.text: Gerti spins - checks out her backside and frowns. She unzips the back.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: No. It’s not a date. It’s professional.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER
dialogues.text: Professional? You’re not a hooker now, are you?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Ha. Ha. Hold on. Gerti puts the phone down and pulls the dress off. She opens the closet door - where the mirror is attached - and finds another dress to try. She slips on a white dress and picks the phone back up.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I mean he works for the same family I work for. We’re like co-workers. Not buying it--

dialogues.speaker: SISTER
dialogues.text: Hm. Are you wearing that white dress? Gerti does a spin. Not too bad. She pours herself a little more wine and takes a drink, posing in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER
dialogues.text: The white dress. You're wearing it right now, aren’t you? Obviously lying--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER
dialogues.text: And you're drinking wine? Gerti’s about to take a drink of wine and stops.  37.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: How do you know all this?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER
dialogues.text: Because I’m your sister. And I know your going-on-a-date routine.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: It’s not a date. I just don’t want to look like a hobo. Besides I-- Gerti sees--

dialogues.speaker: IN THE MIRROR
dialogues.text: BRAHMS sits in the crack of the doorway. His gaze fixed on her.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Lets out a YELP. Turns around to the door, dropping her glass of wine in the process. Glass shatters. Wine sprays all over the white dress-- Brahms stares back at her, that mysterious slight smile on his face. Gerti pushes the door open. Storms past Brahms and into

dialogues.speaker: THE HALLWAY
dialogues.text: She looks up and down. No one in sight. Everything quiet and as normal as this house gets--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Hello? The only sound is Gerti’s sister’s panicked voice on the phone--

dialogues.speaker: SISTER
dialogues.text: Gerti! Are you there!? Gerti? Gerti moves to the top of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Hello? Is somebody here? Silence, save the phone-- Gerti walks back to Brahms sitting innocently in the doorway. She stares at him for a second trying to figure it all out.  38. Then she gives him a good kick, sending Brahms sliding down to the end of the hallway where he ends up sprawled against the wall. INT. GERTI’S ROOM Gerti grabs the phone from the broken glass and wine--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Sandra?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER
dialogues.text: Gerti!? Jesus! You scared me to death. Are you okay? She looks in the mirror. Her white dress covered in drops of red wine. She grabs the black dress--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Yeah. It was Brahms.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Bra--...the doll. Nevermind. This house. I’m just feeling a little stir crazy is all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rush of the water as the shower is turned on. Steam billows out of the shower curtain. Gerti studies her face in the mirror. She makes a sexy face, then sticks her tongue out.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: You're a weird girl, Gert. She hangs the black dress on the towel rod beside the mirror. Then slips off her white wine-stained dress and lets it fall to the floor. Finally she takes off the angel necklace, sets it on the sink, the chain hanging off the side...

dialogues.speaker: SHOWER
dialogues.text: Her body is just barely visible as a silhouette through the shower curtain. Steam has covered the mirror and filled the bathroom.  39. Gerti starts to sing softly to herself as an unseen presence pulls her dress down from the towel rod. Silently tugs the angel necklace down from the sink...

dialogues.speaker: BATHROOM
dialogues.text: Looking into a foggy abyss. With a swipe of a hand Gerti clears an area of mirror. She’s in a towel now. Looks at her face in the mirror. Reaches out, without looking, for her dress. Her hand touches bare metal. Gerti looks over - the towel rack is empty.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Watery footprints as Gerti walks down the hallway, naked. She opens the door to her room - but pauses for a second to look at--

dialogues.speaker: BRAHMS
dialogues.text: Still crumpled in the corner of the hallway where she kicked him. She shakes her head, as if to shake away the though that maybe - just maybe...

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: The light flicks on. Gerti gasps-- The clothes that were everywhere are gone. The underwear flung on the night stand, the jeans thrown on the bed, the sea of dresses laying on the floor. All of it gone. All Gerti can manage to get out--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: No. Gerti lifts a pillow gently, her hand shaking. Nothing. Pulls open a drawer. Empty. PANIC. She whips open the closet door. Empty hangers and stacks of boxes. Gerti tears a box open. Another. She tosses them one by one. Checks her luggage - nothing in those either.  40. She looks dazed, as she walks slowly out of the closet and past the open hallway-door and out of our view. Then, as if in slow-mo rewind she walks back, staring straight through us at:

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: The attic stairs descended. Waiting for her... Gerti rips a sheet off the bed, wraps it around herself. Then steps up to the stairs, staring into the darkness of the attic.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I know you’re up there! I’ve called the police! Silence.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: You better come down right now, you pervert! The wind picks up outside. The windows SHAKE and RATTLE. The house GROANS--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I have a gun! A big fucking gun! And I’m from Texas, I know how to use it! She looks around the empty house. Then to Brahms crumpled in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: (to herself) Don’t go up there. Go into your room and lock the door. As if against her will, she takes a step on the first rung.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Don’t do this, Gert. Another step...

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Don’t take another step... But she does...

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Stop. Call somebody...  41. She takes one more step and pauses. Now, if she steps on her tippy-toes she can just see into the attic. She lifts herself up, slowly, slowly, just enough to peek into the pitch black attic--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I know you’re up there!

dialogues.speaker: WHOOSH
dialogues.text: The stairs raise underneath her. Gerti SCREAMS as she’s thrown into--

dialogues.speaker: THE ATTIC
dialogues.text: Black. Our eyes haven’t adjusted yet. The only sound is Gerti’s BREATHING, coming fast and loud. Then another sound - something in the hallway below. SOFT STEPS. Like a child - or a doll - walking carefully... Our eyes adjust and now we can see Gerti groping in the darkness. A LIGHT from a car outside illuminates the room, makes the shadows shift and move. Gerti crawls to one of the small port-like windows.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: Malcolm's truck. He gets out, moves toward the door--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Malcolm! Help! Malcolm! She slams her fists against the window - wild with fear, SCREAMING for help. Downstairs she hears MORE STEPS - this time moving quickly through the house. Gerti slams on the window and the wall with her fists, while

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: Malcolm walks around the house, looking in windows for any sign of Gerti.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Races through the dark attic, tripping on boxes, fighting her way through the maze of shadows, tugging to keep the sheet on her. She finds what she was looking for - the broken leg of a table. She stumbles back to the window--

dialogues.speaker: SLAM
dialogues.text: She swings the table leg against the window as hard as she can. The window holds. She swings again - this time the table leg snaps in half. The window’s thicker than coke bottle glass.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: Malcolm stands next to his truck, looking confused. He gives the horn a couple of HONKS--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: slams on the glass. SCREAMING, PANICKED--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Malcolm! Up here! Malcolm! But he can’t hear her... Gerti continues SCREAMING and BEATING on the wall as Malcolm climbs into his truck-- Gerti turns back to the room - looking for some way to get Malcolm’s attention or escape. Heads toward a dark corner of the room. Moves quickly through the sea of boxes and random objects and then runs right into

dialogues.speaker: A FIGURE
dialogues.text: Obscured by the darkness. Gerti SCREAMS, stumbles back into a stack of boxes, trips and falls, hitting her head. She doesn’t move. Knocked out cold, the sheet half- draped over her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun rises behind the cottage. The storms have passed, the gray clouds have lifted. No sign of the terror that raged in the night...  43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light spills through the windows, catching the dust that twists and turns like spirits. The attic is filled with fire-damaged furniture. Blackened wood chairs. A half- burnt painting. A fire-melted lamp. Something stirs in a corner.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Opens her eyes. Reaches a hand up and touches a big bump on her head. She grimaces in pain, sits up with a GROAN. Next to her is the FIGURE she ran into in the dark. A DRESSING MANNEQUIN knocked on its side. This too, blackened by some past fire. Behind the mannequin is a LARGE PAINTING, just like the one downstairs with Mr. and Mrs. Heelshire - but in this one it’s not a doll they are posing with, it’s a real boy. The real Brahms. Just beyond the painting a box has been overturned, spilling its contents across the floor. Various baby and toddler clothes, a pair of very small shoes and

dialogues.speaker: A PHOTO ALBUM
dialogues.text: Gerti opens the first page. Various pictures of a BABY, Brahms, and the Heelshires in much happier, much more normal times. Turns the page. Brahms as a toddler, holding the doll Brahms. The same one that Gerti now cares for. Gerti looks through more pictures. Brahms smiling at the camera. Brahms opening birthday presents. Brahms showing a missing tooth. All normal pictures, except in each one the doll is there. Gerti turns another page. Brahms as a young boy. Maybe eight. The smile is gone. A pale, unhappy boy stares at the camera. In most of the pictures he holds the doll over his face. Gerti turns the page again. Only one picture. The only one without the doll. A LITTLE GIRL (8) looks unhappily at the camera while Brahms stares at her. The little girl has blond hair. Freckles. Could easily pass as Gerti’s daughter - or maybe a picture of Gerti as a little girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerti flips through the rest of the book. Empty. It stops there. That’s when Gerti notices--

dialogues.speaker: THE ATTIC DOOR
dialogues.text: It’s open. Gerti peers down the steps. Puts a foot on the top-most rung and then quickly pulls it back up.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: (to herself) Now you’re scared? A beat. Gerti thinks of something, moves through the attic. Picks up the broken chair leg. The only weapon she can find. She stands back at the top of the stairs, holding the leg of the chair. Adjusts the sheet she’s wearing.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I’m coming down! I’m warning you I’m armed! She summons her courage. Slowly, slowly, steps. One step. The next. Then one more, all just as slowly as the first, until she reaches the floor. And there, waiting for her, is a PILE OF HER CLOTHES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The attic stairs are still down. Malcolm walks around them, examining. Gives them a tap with a broom handle. Gerti, clothed now, stands back a few feet and watches. Malcolm gives the stairs another tap. This one a bit harder. Then again and--

dialogues.speaker: WOOSH
dialogues.text: The attic stairs slam closed like the spring on a rat trap. Malcolm looks at Gerti--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Well, that’s one mystery solved.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Gerti waits nervously in the hallway. Arms crossed, maybe because of the cold, maybe out of fright. We can hear Malcolm in the room, moving things around--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Nothing under the bed bars on the window are still solid...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerti gives a quick glance down the hallway to

dialogues.speaker: BRAHMS
dialogues.text: Sitting up now. Hands in his lap like a real, little boy. He’s staring directly at Gerti, almost as if he’s watching her-- Malcolm says something from in the room--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Turns her attention back to the room. Just as she turns her head, she catches sight of Brahms out of the corner of her eye as he BLINKS. Or at least it looks like he does. Gerti does a double-take. Brahms sits there, motionless, inert, harmless - staring back at her with big, black, lifeless eyes...

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ...closet’s clear... Malcolm walks out of the room. Gerti snaps out of her staring contest with Brahms.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: That’s the last room. The house is clear.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Someone was in here, I know it.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: The doors were locked when I got here, there's bars on the windows and I’ve checked every nook and cranny in this very lovely and very large home. I’m not sure what else I can do...

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: But my clothes...  46. Gerti looks down - a bit confused and embarrassed. Could she really have imagined all this?

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: You know, I used to sleep-walk as a boy. One night my parents found me outside in my pajamas washing my bike with my sister's bra. As you can imagine my therapist has a really good time talking about that one. Gerti can’t help but laugh a little--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I don’t know...maybe I was sleep-walking. But she doesn’t look very convinced - or comforted. Gerti’s look isn’t lost on Malcolm--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I could stay a bit longer if you want. Just make sure that we don’t have some very polite burglar on our hands here. Coming in, taking nothing and then locking up after himself when he leaves. Gerti’s face: Yes, yes, yes!

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: No. I feel silly enough already. And I don’t want to inconvenience you...

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: It’s really no problem. I’m here. Just say the word. I could even cook you dinner if you’d like.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I couldn’t ask you to do that...

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: So yes?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: If it’s a hassle or--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Yes? Gerti smiles--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Yes.  47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerti sits at the table - a plate and fork in front of her. Malcolm bursts out of the kitchen holding a baking dish full of steaming food.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Ta-da! He sets the baking-dish down revealing what looks like hot-dogs placed in a kind of uncooked dough. Not exactly appetizing.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Toad-in-the-hole. Just like my mother used to make it.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Toad? Malcolm scoops some out and puts it on Gerti’s plate.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Not to worry. Just a name. Our food’s so bland, we've been forced to give it exotic sounding names to make it more exciting. If we'd invented the hamburger we'd have called it “The Gleaming Jewel of Ipswich Sandwich” or something. He sits down and watches Gerti take her first bite. Gerti takes a bite and chews cautiously--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: And...? Gerti looks a little surprised--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Not bad.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: “Not bad”. The highest compliment a British chef can receive.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Gerti scrapes the remaining food into a big tupperware dish. It’s the one rule handed down from the Heelshires she actually follows. She hands the scraped dishes to Malcolm who washes them in the sink.  48.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: You really don’t have to do that.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: It’s no trouble. You will owe me, of course.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Owe you one? How about a high-five and I tell you your frog-in-the-cave was delicious.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Toad-in-the-hole. And I’m afraid a high- five’s not going to cover it. I believe you still owe me a night on the town. Gerti’s about to reply when - from somewhere upstairs-- TWO LOUD CREAKS like steps. The kind we dismiss as a house “settling”. Both Gerti and Malcolm look up at the ceiling and then at each other, eyes big.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Well, I’m glad this isn’t a big, empty creepy house or that would have been a little spooky, yeah? Gerti smiles--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Yeah. They both return to cleaning up--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: So about this night on the town...

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I’1ll make you a deal? I go out on the town with you in exchange for a little information.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Sounds easy enough.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Tell me more about Brahms. A shift in Malcolm’s face - obviously not a subject he wants to talk about.  49.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I told you about all I know.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: That was truly a terrible poker face. Like one of the worst ever. Malcolm smiles - a serious kind of smile, as if he knows he’s been caught and doesn’t like what’s coming next.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Okay. What do you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: How did he die? Malcolm lets a dish settle underneath the soapy water. Dries his hands, giving full attention to Gerti.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: First, you need to know that Norwich tends to have two kinds of talk. Polite talk and pub talk. And the truth is usually somewhere in between.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: So what’s the polite talk?

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: That it’s no one’s business but the Heelshire’s.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: And the pub talk?

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: That there was a car crash. Or that Brahms was sick. I’ve even heard people say that the Heelshire’s killed him. Which is rubbish. I’ve known them most of my life and there’s no gentler, kinder, more decent people in all of England. A beat. Gerti isn’t exactly sure she wants to keep going anymore.  50.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: And the truth.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: A few years ago I came out here to make a delivery. It was Brahms birthday - or would have been. Mrs. Heelshire was in the living room, opening presents with the doll. Mr. Heelshire was in here, off- his-pickle drunk. I come in and he’s mumbling to himself, just kind of low and sad, about how he can’t do it anymore. I tell him I’1l1 come back another time, but he says, “No, come in. Sit down. Have a drink with me.” So I do. We get a couple of drinks in just chatting about the weather and so on and I finally get the courage to ask him. How did Brahms, the real Brahms die? He looks at me. Kind of shakes his head as if even he doesn’t know anymore. And he says, “Can a boy die of shyness?” And I tell him, “I suppose he could.” “Then that’s what it was,” he says. And then he excused himself and said he’d better get to the birthday party or he was going to catch hell from the missus. So I guess, maybe, that’s as close to an answer as any of us are ever going to get. CREEEAAAAAK. THUD. The house settling... Malcolm and Gerti look up at the ceiling and then back down at each other.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Not spooky at all.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerti stands in front of the mirror, brushing her teeth when--

dialogues.speaker: IN THE MIRROR
dialogues.text: Something FLASHES behind her - maybe just a shadow flickering across the hallway--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spins around and looks into the darkened hallway. Nothing. Just silence and shadows...

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Gerti turns toward her room when she stops. Brahms sits in his same spot at the edge of the hall. Gerti quickly disappears into his room and, just as quickly, re-emerges with a blanket. Gerti tosses the blanket over Brahms, careful to make sure that Brahms’ blank stare is covered. The SOUND OF WOMEN’S VOICES carry over to... INT. GERTI’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Gerti’s in bed, a magazine open in front of her, the phone pressed to her ear--

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: ..-how do you know this guy is safe?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: He’s a family friend of the Heelshire’s.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Oh, so a family friend of the freaky people who pretend a doll is their dead son? That sounds very safe to me.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: He didn’t have to come out here and check the house. Or make me dinner.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: How can you still be so naive? He’s trying to get in your pants, Gert. Men will do whatever it takes to sleep with you.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: He’s not like that. He’s nice. He made dinner, did the dishes and went home. A perfect gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: You watch. You'll wake up in the middle of the night and he’1ll be standing over you in one of your dresses with lipstick smeared all over his face.  52. Gerti laughs--

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: I’m serious, Gert. There are bad people in this world, you should know that better than most. Speaking of bad people... Gerti’s whole body goes rigid-- A beat.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: .»..-Cole has been after me non-stop. He even showed up at my work a couple of times.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: I gave him your address. I’m sorry. I just didn’t know what to do. He came by the house when I wasn’t there and the kids were alone and he just wouldn’t let up with the calls and the... Another beat.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: He said he just wanted to send you a letter. I’m sorry, Gert. I really am, but I can’t have him around my family.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: It’s fine. I can handle it. I’m sorry I dragged you into this.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: When the letter comes, just promise me you'll tear it up, okay? Don’t even look at it. Gerti speaks, but it’s almost as if she’s in some kind of daze now, as if she’s speaking to no one in particular--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Promise me.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I promise.  53.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Good. I have to get the kids up for school. Morgan has a field trip to the zoo today. You take care of yourself, you hear me, Gerti?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: And Gerti...?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I love you too. CLICK. The phone hangs up on the other end of the line. Gerti continues to hold the phone to her ear for a beat, thinking. Another CLICK. As if a second phone is hanging up or maybe picking up--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Hello? Hello? Silence. Gerti hangs up the phone. A look of concern on her face as she sets it on the side-table...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gray, foggy morning. INT. GERTI’S BEDROOM - MORNING Gerti’s still half-asleep. Crawls out of bed--

dialogues.speaker: THE HALLWAY
dialogues.text: And trips over something. She looks down and sees--

dialogues.speaker: SHOES
dialogues.text: The same shoes she lost on her first day. Underneath the shoes are a small stack of papers. Gerti lifts them up-- BRAHMS’ RULES  54. “NEVER LEAVE BRAHMS ALONE” has been circled in red crayon. Gerti looks at the next page - the schedule, starting with Tuesday. Today.

dialogues.speaker: ON GERTI
dialogues.text: The hair standing up on the back of her neck. And then she sees something that makes her go cold-- The hallway is empty. No blanket. No Brahms. Gerti lets the papers fall from her hand... BRAHMS’ ROOM Gerti peeks in and sees: Brahms laying peacefully in a perfectly made bed, just like Mrs. Heelshire would do it. Brahms is facing up, one hand by his side, one hand on his chest, just like a real little boy might sleep. GERTI’S BEDROOM The door slams. Gerti locks it. Grabs the phone and dials. Puts the phone up to her ear and...nothing. It’s dead.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Hello?! She turns the phone on and the off again. Still dead--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Shit... Gerti moves quickly. Shoves the dresser in front of the door. Then she backs away to the opposite wall, holding the phone in front of her like some kind of weapon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun slowly disappears behind a shield of grey clouds on the horizon. Night falls...  55. INT. GERTI’S BEDROOM - NIGHT .-..and Gerti is still in the same place. Waiting. Eyes still on the door. Without making a sound she raises the phone to her ear again, listens. Still dead. At the door-- TAP. TAP. Like little porcelain fingers tapping on the door.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Malcolm? No answer.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Hello? Gerti quietly moves to the door, still blocked by the dresser. She listens again. Silence. She slowly, quietly slides the dresser aside. Gets down on all fours and peers

dialogues.speaker: UNDERNEATH THE DOOR
dialogues.text: There’s something there, it’s hard to tell what it is.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: stands, unlocks the door. Carefully, silently opens it and peeks--

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: A peanut-butter and jelly sandwich sits just outside the door. A glass of wine beside it. The papers, rules and schedule, underneath it.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Closes the door again. Locks it. She’s breathing hard now. Scared. Tired. Hungry. She has that look on her face. What do I do?  56.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: The door opens. Gerti peeks out. Then takes a step out. She picks up the sandwich. Smells it. Opens it up. Just peanut butter and jelly. She picks up the papers stacked neatly underneath the plate...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerti stands over Brahms. He lays there, the little smile on his face. Gerti looks at him and then the papers. She notices something on the list: bath time. Gerti looks at Brahms again. Dirt smudges on his porcelain face. Comes to some decision--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Okay, Brahms...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brahms sits in the bath while Gerti gently wipes the dust and dirt off of his little porcelain face and hands.

dialogues.speaker: DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: Brahms and Gerti sit directly across from each other. Plates of food in front of them. Gerti eats, never taking her eyes off of Brahms. Almost in a whisper--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Brahms? Silence.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Are you there? Can you hear me? She waves her hand in front of his face. Nothing.  57.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Just give me some kind of sign. A blink. Or move or whatever you do, just let me know that you can hear me. Gerti looks up at the ceiling - calls out in her best spirit medium voice--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: If there is a spirit in this house... um...let your presence be known. Beat. Same voice--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Spirit come forth into the land of the living. Give, uh, upon me a sign. A long, silent beat. Brahms remains perfectly still, the same half-smiling look on his face. Finally Gerti stands up. She takes her dish. Walks around the table and picks up Brahms’s untouched plate. Pauses behind Brahms.

dialogues.speaker: RAAAAH
