dialogues.text: She screams directly into Brahms ear. He doesn’t flinch. Doesn't move. Gerti stands there, embarrassed. Looks around as if someone might be watching and then gathers herself and continues into the kitchen as if nothing happened...

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Classical music is BLASTING. Gerti and Brahms sit side by side on the couch. The music is so loud Gerti has her fingers in her ears. She takes one finger out just long enough to turn a page in her magazine... INT. BRAHM’S ROOM - NIGHT Gerti tucks Brahms into his bed. She turns off his light and stands there for a moment. Under the moonlight he almost looks like a real little boy. A flash of tenderness on Gerti’s face. She softens. Relaxes for the first time.  58. Gerti bends down and kisses Brahms lightly on the cheek. Then leaves the room, closing the door behind her...

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Gerti turns to walk to her room. Stops. Something suddenly occurring to her. Reverses course and walks to-- MR. AND MRS. HEELSHIRE’S ROOM Gerti heads directly to the bedside table. Opens the drawer and takes out the envelope. She sits down on the bed. Waits a moment. Maybe building up courage. Then pulls out the contents. “LAST WILL AND TESTAMENT” written at the top. Lower on the page Gerti finds what she was looking for. The typed words “conservator of the Heelshire estate and fortunes” followed by a blank underlined portion that’s been filled in with Mrs. Heelshire’s perfect handwriting with two words: Gertrude Evans

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain coming down in sheets. A small bare cabin the same color of the sand and driftwood surrounding it. Thick fog moves like ghosts across the land. We can just hear the sound of the ocean waves above the rain..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first page of a letter sits on the table in front of Mrs. Heelshire. She’s busy now, writing the second. We pass over the first page, catching snippets here and there, things like: “...can’t bare to live with what we allowed you to become” and “Gerti is your doll now, yours to love and care for..” We move across the table to the letter Mrs. Heelshire is finishing the letter. She writes, “May God forgive us all” and then “Love always, Mother”. Mr. Heelshire puts a hand on Mrs. Heelshire’s shoulder--  59.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HEELSHIRE
dialogues.text: It’s time mother. Mrs. Heelshire nods sadly. Stuffs the letter into an envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. and Mrs. Heelshire walk down a gravel path to a post- box. Mrs. Heelshire reaches into her jacket pocket, produces a letter. We get a quick look at it, Mrs. Heelshire’s distinctive writing - addressed to Brahms. Mrs. Heelshire stuffs it in the mailbox and lifts the letter flag. Then she and Mr. Heelshire join hands and continue their walk...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They make their way slowly down the beach. Mr. Heelshire stops, picks up a couple of large-ish stones. One he puts in the pocket of his heavy winter jacket. The other he hands to Mrs. Heelshire who puts it in the pocket of her own jacket. This continues - the couple stopping and picking up stones every couple of feet - until they reach the edge of the sea. Mr. Heelshire takes Mrs. Heelshire’s hand in his. Then the couple - hand in hand - walk straight toward the sea. The ice-cold water rushes against their feet, rises up to their ankles and then the sea foam is up to their knees and they keep walking, bending over to push themselves into the waves-- Mrs. Heelshire struggles against the waves until they reach up to her neck. A large swell hits the couple and Mrs. Heelshire disappears. Mr. Heelshire struggles on. Another wave and Mr. Heelshire, too, disappears. And then it’s as if they were never there - just the beating of the waves on the sand and the rain erasing any trace of their footprints...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something GOLDEN glimmers in front of Gerti’s door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opens. Walks out and sees

dialogues.speaker: A GOLDEN NECKLACE
dialogues.text: An antique. Expensive looking. Diamonds decorate a large gold pendant. A gift from Brahms. BRAHMS’ ROOM - CONTINUOUS Gerti stands in the doorway. Looks at Brahms, sitting under the covers just as she left him. She looks down at the necklace in her hand. Then slips it in her pocket and lifts Brahms up. Then, for the first time, speaks to Brahms as if he was a real, live little boy. Tenderly, motherly--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Wake-up, sweet-heart. Time for breakfast...

dialogues.speaker: INT. ENTRANCE WAY
dialogues.text: The sound of TALKING. At first it almost sounds like two people talking. We push through the house to the

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Gerti and Brahms sit side by side on the floor. A stack of records in front of them. Gerti flips through them--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Classical...classical...classical... Liberace. I’m not sure what kind of music that is. We really need to get you some new music, Brahms. How does that sound? Gerti pauses, looks at Brahms for some kind of reaction.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How about some REO Speedwagon? Gerti just about jumps out of her skin. Malcolm stands just inside the room. He smiles--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Sorry. REO Speedwagon is a bit scary. Maybe we'll start with something a bit milder. Maybe some Wham?  61. Gerti LAUGHS. Malcolm hold up some mail - a few bills and the letter to Brahms. A flash of worry on Gerti’s face--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Anything for me?

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: ‘fraid not.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: You can put it in the mail vase. Gerti motions toward a large vase filled with various pieces of mail--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Mail vase. Very classy. Malcom drops the mail in. We can see the letter from Mrs. Heelshire stuffed in with the rest...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brahms is positioned carefully at the table. A sandwich and a glass of milk sit untouched in front of him. Malcolm gives the whole set-up a scrutinizing look before he puts away a can of beans. Gerti packs the fridge with vegetables.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I see you and Brahms are getting on. Gerti looks up from the fridge and smiles - one of those mysterious, inside joke kind of smiles.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Yeah. Gerti goes back to her work. Malcolm watches her for a beat, aware that something strange is going on, but not quite sure what it is...

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I thought I might take you up on that night-on-the-town offer. Dinner. Drinks. Dancing. I'11l have you know I’m a legend in these parts for my dance moves. Not because they’re good, mind you - but a legend’s a legend.  62.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I don’t think I should.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I’m afraid I can’t take no for an answer. If I let you return to America without ever showing you more than this dreary mansion I won’t be able to forgive myself.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I really shouldn’t leave, Brahms...

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Is that all it is then? Let’s ask him, yeah? I’m sure he won’t mind. Malcolm walks over to Brahms-- MALCOLM (CONT’D) Brahms, you, old sod, would you mind terribly if I take the lovely Miss Evans out for a night on the town? As Brahms-- MALCOLM (CONT’D) Why of course not. I’ve been hoping she’d get out of the house. I need a little privacy. Think I’1l watch telly. Take a nice bubble bath. Have a little Brahms’ time. Gerti watches - not amused. Her hands clenched. Malcolm, oblivious, continues his routine. Now he switches to a Senor Wences impression-- MALCOLM (CONT’D) Is alright? S‘alright. He holds up Brahms’ hand and gives himself a high five. Gerti can’t take anymore.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: (a little too loud) Stop! Malcolm freezes. Then let’s out an uncomfortable laugh.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I was just joking--  63. Malcolm gives Brahms a couple of knocks on the head, as if to emphasize he’s just porcelain. Gerti rushes over, re-adjusts him, putting his hands back where they were--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Just don’t. Don’t touch him.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I’m sorry...I... And for once Malcolm doesn’t have the words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm gets into his

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK
dialogues.text: He sits there a moment, looking at the Heelshire Manor, a kind of “What the hell just happened” look on his face. A curtain moves in an upstairs window, as if someone was peeking on him, watching... Malcolm doesn’t see it. Starts up his truck--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Crazy bloody American... The rest is just grumbling as he drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s turned into a beautiful day. Afternoon sunlight spills through the window illuminating the thin veil of dust hanging in the air. Brahms is seated at his desk while Gerti stands at the podium reading from some children’s book in a LOUD, CLEAR VOICE - just as she was instructed by Mrs. Heelshire. THE PHONE RINGS in another room. Gerti pauses - just long enough to let it register. RING. RING. Then she continues reading while the phone RINGS and RINGS...  64. INT. GERTI’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Gerti lays on her bed, talking on the phone. Brahms is propped next to her--

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: I’ve been trying to call you all week. I was about to call the boobies.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: The boobies?

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: The British police. You’re lucky Rick talked me out of it.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: It's Bobbies, Sandy.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: I don’t care what they’re called. You can’t just stop answering your phone. I worry about you.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, there was a, uh...a problem with the phone.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Is it fixed now? You can’t be out there with no phone. Gerti looks at Brahms--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Yeah, everything’s fine now.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Are you sure you’re okay? You sound, I don’t know. You just sound different. As if realizing it for the first time--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’m good. A SIGH on the other end of the line - as if Sandy doesn’t quite buy it--

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Well, in two months you'll be back here and everything will be back to normal. Gerti looks less than happy about it--  65.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lunchtime. Brahms sits at the table alone. We PUSH IN on Brahms’ face. It almost looks like his expression is changing - ever so slightly - from that mysterious half-smile to something darker and more sinister...

dialogues.speaker: GERTI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don’t know what kind of food you like, but until you say otherwise it’s sandwich city for you. Gerti emerges from the kitchen with a sandwich and a glass of milk. She’s smiling, happy - at home. Gerti sets the plate down in front of Brahms.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: So what do you feel like doing today? How about we forget the schedule and do something fun? Hide-and-seek? Play some checkers? Maybe go for a walk outside? A beat. Gerti waits.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: No? Okay. Well, we’ll stick to the schedule then. We FOLLOW GERTI as she walks back into --

dialogues.speaker: THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: She starts making another sandwich for herself.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I gotta be honest with you, Brahms. This schedule thing is getting to me. I don’t see how you do it. Same thing every day. Not leaving this house. I’ma girl that needs a little spontaneity. I just can’t do the same thing everyday. I need adventure. I need surprises. I might need to get out of the house for a couple of days here... We FOLLOW GERTI back into the  66.

dialogues.speaker: DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: Gerti freezes, her mouth hanging open. Brahms is gone. The chair pushed back and away from the table. Gerti looks around the room--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Brahms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truck tires come to a skidding stop in the gravel driveway.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Jumps out of the truck. Practically runs up to the front door. The door swings open and there’s Gerti, wild-eyed and half-crazy looking.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I...uh...I. He. Brahms. He just. Gerti starts LAUGHING - somewhere in between hysterical and joyous. Gathers herself--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: You're not going to believe this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerti races up the stairs, Malcolm struggles to keep up--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I needed someone to see it too. So I'd know I wasn’t crazy.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: To see what too? Gerti suddenly stops - looks at Malcolm beaming happily--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: He's alive. A beat. Malcolm doesn’t get it--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Who's alive?  67.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Brahms.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Brahms is alive?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Maybe not alive. I don’t know. He’s...something. Gerti starts up the stairs again-- Malcolm BRAHMS ’ Gerti’s circles Malcolm

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: You just have to see it. pauses before following her--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: (to himself) Christ...

dialogues.speaker: ROOM
dialogues.text: on her hands and knees wiping chalk lines and off of the floor. Brahms is seated on the bed. stands in the doorway looking more than a little uncomfortable. He goes to talk and then doesn’t. Starts again. Stops again...

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Are you sure you’re feeling alright?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I know you must think I’m crazy. I'd think the same thing. She scrubs at the floor--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I have to erase this, so you don’t think I'm cheating--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I don’t think you’re cheating. No worries there. (to himself) I think you’ve gone completely fucking mad’s what I think... Gerti stands up smiling.  68.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Come inside. Look around. Malcolm steps inside the room cautiously. Looks around.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: What is it, exactly, that I’m looking for?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Make sure there’s no one here. It’s just Brahms. Taking nothing for granted--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Um...we’re here. Gerti smiles at him - a big joyous, or maybe, insane smile. It’s hard to tell--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: But we won’t be. She sets Brahms on the floor and then carefully draws a circle around him.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I use the chalk because sometimes he doesn’t move very much and it’s hard to tell. I knew I had to be scientific about it. I even measured it at first. I don’t want any doubt when it happens. She stands again. Stares straight into Malcolm's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is something... She shakes her head, like there’s not a word big enough--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: +..this is SOMETHING. All Malcolm can do is nod.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Gerti closes the door to Brahms’ room. Gerti and Malcolm walk into--  69. GERTI’S ROOM Disaster. Clothes everywhere. They have to walk over them just to get in. Malcolm looks around, lifts up clothes as if looking for clues to the tragedy unfolding before him--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I couldn't figure it out before. There were these strange things going on. Little things. Sounds. A necklace. My shoes that I lost. She gives the wall TWO KNOCKS - as if a signal--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And then I remembered what you said. He’s shy. He doesn’t want people to see. But if you go into another room, if you leave him alone, he'll give you sign.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: This is like a magic trick, yeah? You don’t really think he’s alive?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: It’s not a trick. Gerti walks out of the room--

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Gerti and Malcolm stand in front of the closed door to Brahms’ room. Tense. They look at each other. Even Malcolm's starting to believe a little--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Are you ready? Malcolm doesn’t look ready, but--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Okay. (to the door) Brahms, here we come... Gerti reaches out to the door-knob. Gives it a slow turn and pushes the door open--  70.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: Brahms sits, still very much inside the circle. Just as Gerti left him. Gerti’s smiles fades. Malcolm puts his arm around her--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: It's okay. I think maybe we should sit down for a bit, yeah? Honestly, I think maybe you're a bit tired. Gerti pulls away--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: No... She kneels down to Brahms--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please, Brahms. I need him to see. I know you’re scared. I know this is hard for you. Do it for me, okay? I need this or I can’t stay here any more. It’s pitiful to watch. Malcolm rubs his face hard with his hand--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Gerti... Gerti stands--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: One more time. If nothing happens then I'm crazy. I'll sit. I’ll rest. I/’11 leave. Whatever you want. Just one more time. GERTI’S ROOM Gerti gives the wall between her room and Brahms room a firm knock. Once. Twice. Malcolm paces the floor, a continual creaking with each footstep. He stops - the creaking doesn’t. It’s coming from the other room. Malcolm and Gerti look at each other--  71.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Standing before the door to Brahms’s room again. Even more tense this time. Gerti reaches out for the door knob and stops. She pulls back afraid. She looks at Malcolm. He nods. Malcolm reaches out. Opens the door--

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: An empty circle - with no Brahms. Malcolm lets out a gasp. Gerti lets out a LAUGH that’s almost a cry. A kind of joyous release - she’s not crazy!

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Bloody... They walk into the room. Malcolm looks around. No sign of Brahms. MALCOLM (CONT’D) Where'd he go? Gerti just smiles and shrugs--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Malcolm looks under the bed.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s real isn’t it? Next he looks through the closet. Pushing through piles of Brahms’ clothing.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Bloody...

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: (to herself) It’s real. Malcolm stands next to Gerti looking completely confused.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I don’t understand. Gerti throws her arms around Malcolm. His confusion drains away as he feels her body pressed into his. He puts his arms around her.  72. And then Malcolm sees something over her shoulder. He goes completely still. Gerti turns around and sees:

dialogues.speaker: BRAHMS
dialogues.text: sitting just outside the room in the hallway - just like someone placed him there. Gerti laughs.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Now Brahms, be a good boy. Don’t scare Malcolm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red wine filling a glass all the way to the top... Malcolm and Gerti sit on the couch drinking wine looking giddy and maybe more than a little drunk. Brahms is seated in a chair facing them. MUSIC plays in the background. Not as loud as Brahms’ likes it, but loud enough--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Can he hear me?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: It's bloody incredible, isn’t it? It’s gigantic. It’s huge. I don’t even know how to feel. I’m half scared out of my mind and half...I don’t know...amazed. I mean, my mind is just... He makes a “mind blowing” motion. Malcolm talks quickly, half from the wine and half from the excitement.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: What do we do now? Do we tell someone? Go to the papers. Have experts come in? Have those blokes, those ghost hunting blokes from the reality TV come in and take a look. Do tests or, I don’t know, a seance. We really don’t even know what we're dealing with, yeah? Is it a ghost? Some sort of trapped spirit. Or a...a...

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: A little boy. Brahms is a little boy. Malcolm stops. Catches his breath--  73.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Of course. Yeah. (to Brahms ) Sorry about that, mate. Malcolm pours them both more wine. He smiles at Gerti. She looks beautiful, happy. A little flushed with wine--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: You're lucky you found her, Brahms. Not all nannies are as nice as this one.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: It wasn’t luck. Gerti blushes. The words just slipped out--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: What do you mean? Gerti shakes her head, embarrassed--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: It’s the wine talking. I’m not much of a drinker.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: You can’t stop now, you’ve got me curious. It wasn’t luck?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: You'll think I’m crazy.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I‘1l have you know I just played several rounds of hide-and-seek with a - no offense, Brahms - a doll. I doubt very much you can tell me anything that can make me think you're crazy. Gerti takes a big drink of wine, building courage. Clears her throat--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I, uh...I prayed for this.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: You prayed for a haunted doll? Gerti LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: No, not exactly. I mean...  74. We can see Gerti sorting the whole thing out in her head. Maybe she doesn’t even know what she means. Or maybe she does - but she’s been avoiding the truth--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: There was a guy. Back home.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: A boyfriend? Gerti nods - yes--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Cole Perkins. It was one of those things. We met in high school and he was charming and funny. And handsome. I thought I was the luckiest girl in Texas. But something changed. I don’t even know when it happened. At first I thought it was just stress or him worrying. But it just kept happening. This switch would flip inside him and just like that the man I knew’d be gone and standing there in his place would be this monster, just screaming and hollering and... Gerti doesn’t say it, but we know by the look on her face - hitting her.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Afterwards I'd pack up and go stay with my sister or my aunt. A day later Cole’d show up with flowers and beg me to come back and tell me how he’d changed and I'd believe him and go. And it’d be good for a while, then it wouldn’t. It went like that over and over until everyone I knew’d given up on me. Not that I blame them, I’d given up on me too. I thought, “Well, this is the way it’s gonna be, Gert, you better get used to it.” Gerti takes another drink of wine--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: And then I found out I was pregnant. A beat. A pained smile on Gerti’s face. She looks at Brahms now, almost as if she’s telling him the story--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I’m sitting in the doctor’s office sobbing. The nurse is telling me what a blessing it is. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: GERTI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How everything is gonna change for the better now. But I knew better. I knew I couldn’t have that baby. Not into this world. Not with Cole. How could I expect to protect a baby when I couldn’t even protect myself? I knew I wasn’t strong enough. That I wasn’t brave enough... Gerti starts to cry silently--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: So I didn’t have it and I ran away from everything and came here. But ever since that day I’ve prayed and I've wished for some kind of sign. I don’t even know what I was asking for. Just something to let me know that life wasn’t so small. So mean. She motions to Brahms. Smiles through the tears--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: And now here’s Brahms. And I can’t help but feel like maybe he was praying for me too. Like we were the answers to each others prayers. I'd felt so empty for so long and now, finally, I’m starting to feel whole again. Like a real person. And I think maybe he feels the same way. Gerti reaches up, touches her tears, not even aware she was crying--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I’m crying. I’m sorry. I warned you I’m not much of a drinker and now I’m rambling on and on...

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: No. Don’t be sorry. I like the way you ramble. You have a very nice ramble. Gerti laughs, that sad little laugh. Somehow crying has made her look even more beautiful. Malcolm reaches out to wipe a tear away and there’s a moment - a moment that we know there’s something between them. A beat. Malcolm goes to say something, but before he can get it out Gerti kisses him. A hard, passionate, half-drunk kiss...  76. INT. BRAHMS’ ROOM - NIGHT Gerti tucks Brahms in. She leans down and kisses him on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I promise I’1l never leave you. She switches the light off and the room goes black. We follow Gerti as she walks out into the HALLWAY and then to her BEDROOM -— CONTINUOUS Gerti walks into a dark room. A figure sitting on the bed stands up. Malcolm. Gerti moves toward him and the two of them stand there awkwardly for a beat. The two of them are drunk, but not quite drunk enough to keep from feeling a little shy--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: So... Gerti steps in close toward him, close enough to kiss him. But she keeps her head down, staring at his chest shyly.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: This is a nice shirt.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: My mum bought it for me. Gerti undoes the top button--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: She has good taste.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I‘ll let her know... And with that Malcolm tips Gerti’s chin upwards and kisses her, softly and then harder, pulling her back onto the bed. We PULL BACK...out of the room and into the hallway where we can see into both Gerti and Brahms’ room. Something MOVES in Brahms room as we... FADE OUT...  77. INT. GERTI’S BEDROOM - MORNING Early morning. Gerti and Malcolm are tangled in the sheets, asleep. We hold on them as-- STEPS. Soft as a doll’s footsteps.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE FLOOR
dialogues.text: A pile of Malcom’s clothes. Something - or someone - just out of view, drags Malcolm’s shirt from the pile. It’s the same one Gerti complimented. More STEPS. We turn just as-- THE BEDROOM DOOR CLOSES quietly. Someone sneaking out. A silent beat and then--

dialogues.speaker: BOOM
dialogues.text: Something pounding at the door. Gerti and Malcolm bolt up in bed.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: What in the-- Panic. Malcolm scrambles out of bed, tripping over the sheets and landing with a THUD. He gets back up, heads to the door--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Malcolm, no-- More POUNDING on the door. Not the kind of noise a doll could make. Malcolm looks at Gerti and then--

dialogues.speaker: WHIPS THE DOOR OPEN REVEALING
dialogues.text: The doll. Sitting there in front of him. Malcolm sticks his head out into the hallway. Empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breakfast. Gerti, Malcolm and Brahms at the table. Malcolm wears one of Gerti’s t-shirts - a too-tight “Hook ‘em Horns” Texas shirt. He doesn’t look too happy about it.  78.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: He likes to play little tricks on people. It means he likes you. To Brahms--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Very funny. You know what would be even funnier? If you gave my shirt back. Gerti can’t help but LAUGH. EXT. HEELSHIRE MANOR —- MORNING Gerti walks Malcolm to his truck. They stop before it - smile at each other awkwardly. Malcolm looks back at the house nervously. Something’s on his mind--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I was thinking, why don’t you come in town for a few days? Get out of this house for a bit.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I admire your persistence, but I don’t think I should. Brahms needs me here. Malcolm shifts uncomfortably--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: What happened this morning. With the door. That was--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: It was a tantrum. Children have tantrums. I shouldn’t have-- Gerti stops, blushing.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I’m not supposed to have guests. This is his house.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: One night away. To get some perspective and we can figure out what all this is.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: You know I can’t leave. I promised the Heelshires I'd take care of Brahms.  79.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Under the circumstances I think the Heelshire’s would understand. When they get back--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: They aren’t coming back. It just slipped out. But Gerti knows it’s true--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I found a will. My name was in it. That’s why they looked for so long. They had to find the right person to take over for them. They were waiting for me. I’m the only person Brahms has now.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Whatever you saw, I’m sure it’s just some kind of emergency plan or something. You don’t really think that they went off and... The look on Gerti’s face: Yes, she does.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: If you really believe that, it’s even more reason to step back. To look at this with clear eyes--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I’m not leaving. Not for a day. Not for an hour. For the first time Malcolm looks truly shook up. He rubs his face hard with his hand--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: There’s something I need to tell you. About Brahms. I should have told you before, but I didn’t want to scare you away. And now...well, maybe you should be scared. (beat) There was a man one night in the pub I go to. He was from the same town as the Heelshires. He’d known them as a boy. He said they used to pay kids to come out and play with Brahms. He’d even gone out there once, but Brahms wouldn’t come out of his room the entire time he was there. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But they eventually found someone he liked. A little girl. She’d go out there once a week to play with Brahms then walk home. But one night she doesn’t come home. Her parents call the Heelshires. The Heelshires tell them Brahms just left to walk her home. The parents wait until dark. The little girl still doesn’t show up. So they decide to go out there and look for her themselves. When they get to the Heelshire’s house it’s up in flames. Mr. and Mrs. Heelshire made it out. But Brahms...he didn’t. He said it was two days later that they finally found the girl. Dead. Hidden in some bushes along the trail she took to walk home. (beat) What I’m saying is, if this is some kind of spirit or ghost or...whatever it is. I’m not sure it’s the good kind.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: It’s not true. I can feel him. I know him. You said yourself it’s just pub talk.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Not this. This was different. He said it was a childhood friend of his. Emily. And the look in his eyes...

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I won't leave him. He needs me. Malcolm reaches out to Gerti--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Just one day-- Gerti pulls away from Malcolm - HARD--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I think it’s best if you don’t come over for a few days.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I’m trying to help you.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I don’t need your help.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Gerti...  81. But Gerti’s already walking back to the house--

dialogues.speaker: INT. ENTRANCE WAY
dialogues.text: Gerti closes the front door behind her. Looks at Brahms sitting on the couch. A beat. The sound of MALCOLM’S TRUCK leaving outside. She looks upstairs, something nagging at her. Suddenly heads for the stairs--

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Comes out of the Heelshire’s room, walking fast. Carrying the attic pole. Pulls down the attic stairs and goes up--

dialogues.speaker: ATTIC
dialogues.text: Gerti moves through the burnt remains of furniture. Finds the photo album and flips through quickly. Finds what she was looking for--

dialogues.speaker: THE PHOTO OF BRAHMS AND THE LITTLE GIRL
dialogues.text: Gerti takes out the picture. Flips to the back. Written in Mrs. Heelshire’s handwriting “Brahms Heelshire & Emily Cribbs”. Gerti looks up from the photograph. At all the half- burned objects around her. They somehow seem menacing now. Gruesome. For the first time since she discovered Brahms was alive, Gerti looks afraid... INT. MALCOLM’S TRUCK - DAY Some POP SONG plays on the radio. Malcolm drives.

dialogues.speaker: A FAINT SCRATCHING SOUND
dialogues.text: Malcolm listens. SCRATCH. SCRATCH. He turns off the radio. More SCRATCHING. It’s faint, but it’s definitely there.  82. Malcolm keeps driving as he leans forward, listening. Trying to figure out where the sound is coming from. He taps the GLOVE BOX and the SOUND STOPS. Keeping one eye on the road Malcolm reaches over and opens the glove box. THREE BLOODY, HALF-DEAD RATS come tumbling out. One goes scurrying towards Malcolm's feet.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: SHOUTS, swerves off the road into a field before he manages to SLAM ON THE BREAKS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm jumps out of the truck and does one of those creeped-out dances in the field, cursing loudly--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Classical music THUNDERS on the stereo - through all the empty rooms of Heelshire manor. The sound of music carries over to-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where it carries into the open air. Gerti walks around the house with a garbage bag. She stops at a bush and reaches behind it, bringing up an empty rat trap. Gerti sets it back and heads to the next one. She pulls it up - empty. She rounds the house to the front and stops. Drops her garbage bag. A confused, shocked look on her face--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: (barely audible) Cole?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLE PERKINS(mid-30's). Tall, all-American looking with sandy-blonde hair. He looks like some kind of a harder- lived version of Troy Aikman. He gives her an apologetic, almost shy, smile.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: I was going to send you a letter, but, you know me, I was never one for writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerti and Brahms sit side by side on the couch. Cole sits on a chair facing them, leaning forward toward Gerti.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: This is a joke, right? Gerti doesn’t look up. She reaches out and puts a comforting arm around Brahms. Cole grimaces, rubs his face hard - partly puzzled, partly frustrated. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: The whole way out here I was thinking of what I was going to say. How I was going to convince you to forgive me and to come back to Denton. I had this speech worked out, but now...I mean, this, this is... Cole looks at Brahms, still not quite believing what he’s seeing. He reaches into his bag, pulls out two plane tickets and tosses them on the coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Our flight leaves tomorrow afternoon. You're coming home. Gerti squeezes Brahms tighter to her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerti and Cole at the dinner table. Brahms is tossed haphazardly on of the chairs-—-

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: I been working out at Fairview with Ed Bruner’s crew. They got a contract to put in a new hotel, so there’s more than enough work for all of us. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: COLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ed says “hi” by the way. Actually he said-- (in a thick, exaggerated Texas drawl) “You tell Gert to get her cute little hind-end back here to Texas where she belongs.” Gerti can’t help but smile a little.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: There it is, that famous Gerti smile. I missed that smile. (beat) You know I love you? Gerti nods.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: I know I’ve done some stupid things. I've done wrong by you. But I’m finished with all that, I swear. I had a lot of time to think while you were gone. You've been right about everything. You were right all along. I get it now. I really do. Things are going to be better from now on. I can’t live without you, baby. I just can’t. He kisses her on the forehead. The nose. And then, finally, on the lips. Gerti doesn’t kiss him back, she just sits there, taking it.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I let myself in. Malcolm stands in the doorway. Gerti shoots hima panicked look - please don’t say anything...

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Cole, this is Malcolm. He brings us our groceries out here. Cole stands up, towering over Malcolm and offers his hand. Malcolm shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: So what do you think of all this doll stuff? Malcolm looks at Gerti, not sure what to say. Gerti shakes her head, “No”.  85.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I try not to get involved in other people’s affairs. Cole laughs--

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Smart man.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: (to Gerti) I have that delivery if you want to go over the inventory list.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Yeah. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Malcolm and Gerti duck into a corner of the kitchen, away from the door. Malcolm tries to whisper but it comes out loud--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: What in the-- Gerti puts her finger to her lips - Shh. Whispering--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: He just showed up. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: He wants me to go home with him. Malcolm heads toward the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I think I should have a little talk with him-- Gerti grabs him--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Don’t. Please. You'll only make it worse.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: If you think I’m letting him--  86.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: You don’t know him, Malcolm. You don’t know what he’ll do. When he gets angry...He’1ll hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I’m not afraid of him.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: He’1l hurt me. Malcolm stops.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I know what I’m doing. You have to trust me. Malcolm thinks it over--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I can’t leave you here with him. What if he--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: He won’t. He’s going to be on his best behavior for now. And I have Brahms here. Gerti speaks louder now - loud enough for Cole to hear in the next room.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Looks good. Thanks, Malcolm. Then, in a whisper--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: If you want to help come back tomorrow. There’s nothing you can do tonight.

dialogues.speaker: DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: Gerti walks back in, followed by Malcolm. Malcolm has a big, friendly grin on his face. If we didn’t know better we might think he was saying goodbye to a good friend--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: It was a pleasure meeting you.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: You too.  87. Malcolm leaves. Cole eats. Gerti watches him. The only sound is Cole chewing loudly. Cole waits until he hears the sound of the door closing in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Should I be worried? He says it with a smile and a little laugh, but it’s obvious he couldn’t be more serious.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: About Malcolm? Cole nods.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: No. Gerti looks to where Brahms is tossed down on a chair and we can almost read her thoughts: But maybe you should be worried about Brahms...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole watches from the doorway as Gerti undresses Brahms and puts pajamas on him--

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: At least I know what to get you for Christmas now. Gerti tucks Brahms into the bed. Bends down and gives him a kiss, whispering something to him. Cole gives a disgusted look--

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Jesus, don’t do that. Gerti stands up, careful not to look at Cole. She doesn’t say anything.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: I’m not going to let you treat this thing like it’s real. Not in front of me.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: He is real.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: He’s real? Okay.  88. Cole picks up Brahms.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Hello!? Anybody there? Are you real? Cole knocks on Brahms’ head, hard.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Come on! If you’re real just speak up. Gerti stands there, frozen. Cole finally tosses Brahms back on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Looks like he’s just a doll after all. Gerti goes to tuck Brahms back into bed, but Cole stops her.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Don’t. A beat. For a second it looks like Gerti might say something, but she thinks better of it.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Go get packed. We leave in the morning. Cole waits until Gerti walks out, then turns off the light behind her. INT. GERTI’S ROOM - NIGHT Gerti closes her door. She goes to the wall she shares with Brahms’ room. Barely above a whisper--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I need your help. He’s going to take me away, Brahms. I need you. Please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dark, silent night. And then a sound. CAREFUL STEPS on a wood floor. CREAK. CREAK. The sound of the steps carry over to...  89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAHMS’ POV: Moving through the upstairs hallway. We pause at Gerti’s closed bedroom door and continue to...

dialogues.speaker: THE STAIRS
dialogues.text: Moving slowly, purposely. CREAK. CREAK. CREAK.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: We're standing over Cole. He’s sleeping, curled up on the too-small couch.

dialogues.speaker: A DROP OF BLOOD
dialogues.text: falls on his face, dropped from somewhere just out of frame. Then another drop. And another. Cole stirs, wipes at it with his hand, smearing it, but he doesn’t wake up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun peaks up behind the hillside. Fog lifts from dew- spangled earth... INT. GERTI’S BEDROOM - MORNING Gerti stirs. Wakes. She looks tired, broken. Pulls herself out of bed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dresses Brahms. Talking to him softly as she does--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Everything will be okay. He’1ll leave and we'll go back to the way things were... Rumblings from downstairs. Like someone talking to themselves. Then an angry SHOUT--

dialogues.speaker: COLE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Gerti! GERTI! A flash of fear on Gerti’s face. She picks up Brahms, holding him close. The storm is coming...  90.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Gerti stops in the doorway, afraid to enter. Cole doesn’t notice her at first. Scrubs his face with his t- shirt. Finally he turns and sees her, his face smeared with blood--

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Get in here! Gerti doesn’t move. Cole’s eyes are wild - filled with rage. The eyes of some animal--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Get in here! Gerti takes a hesitant step in the room. Cole violently grabs her by the arm and drags her to face the wall.

dialogues.speaker: LEAVE
dialogues.text: Written in blood. Below it are two dead rats lying in a small pool of blood.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I didn’t-- Cole jerks her violently--

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Don’t pull this shit on me, Gerti...

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: It wasn’t me. She looks down at Brahms.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: The doll? The doll wrote this? Gerti doesn’t say anything. She’s terrified.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Fine. Okay. It wasn’t you. It was the doll. Give it to me. Gerti backs away.  gl.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Hand him over.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: No. Please...

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Don’t play around with me. I’ve had as much as I can take with you.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I did it. You were right.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: It’s too late for that. I gave you a chance to come clean. Give me that doll. Now. I’m not joking around. He lunges at Gerti, grabs her. The two struggle, but Gerti’s no match for Cole. He rips the doll out of her arms with one hand and pushes her down to the floor with the other.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: No! In a flash Gerti is back on her feet. She lunges at Cole who holds her back with one hand. Lifts the doll over his head with the other. He’s about to smash the doll on the floor when--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Stop! Cole looks over to Malcolm, standing in the Entrance-way.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Get your things. Get out. Cole pulls away from Gerti, still holding Brahms. Cole motions to the wall.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Everyone seems to be in a big hurry for me to leave. Maybe you’re the one that left me this little message. Or are you going to say it was the doll too? Malcolm doesn’t answer.  92.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Cole, you don’t understand. He’s real. He’s just a little boy. Please, let him go, please... Cole looks at Brahms - holding him up for appraisal.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: He's real, huh? Let’s see about that. And then he does something that they’1l all regret.

dialogues.speaker: HE SLAMS BRAHMS DOWN
dialogues.text: Headfirst. Into the ground. The CRASH of porcelain breaking. Jagged pieces of Brahms’ head fly in different directions. A beat. Silence. No one even breaths. Cole smiles, about to say something when--

dialogues.speaker: A SCREAM OF RAGE
dialogues.text: Like we've never heard. So loud the WALLS VIBRATE. And then POUNDING AT THE WALLS. Like a THOUSAND FISTS beating at the house. A picture falls from the wall with a crash. A bookcase overturns. A sound LIKE RUNNING. A stampede coming from every direction at once. Gerti, Malcolm and Cole spin around, trying to follow the sounds--

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: What the hell is that? The SOUND OF A DOOR OPENING, but not any door anyone can see. A FLASH of something out of the corner of Malcolm’s eye moving outside--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I think we need to get out of here... AT THE FRONT DOOR. The scraping of wood and metal together. Something locking them in. Malcolm inches next to Gerti.  93.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I really, really think we need to leave.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: What is this? What is going on!? A loud SLAM, somewhere back in the kitchen and then silence. More POUNDING, moving through the house and then--

dialogues.speaker: SILENCE
dialogues.text: Everyone freezes in the center of the Living Room where they've instinctively huddled into a group.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Brahms? The sounds of SHUFFLING coming from somewhere in the walls, moving fast--

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: It’s in the walls... Cole moves towards the sound--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I really think we should--

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Shhh! Cole puts his ear to the wall. HEAVY BREATHING. Like some cornered, wild animal-- Without moving his ear from the wall--

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Something’s in there...

dialogues.speaker: SLAM
dialogues.text: A KNIFE BLADE rips through the wall. Hits Cole between the neck and shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: SCREAMS FROM EVERYONE
dialogues.text: Cole falls to the floor. Reaches for his wound. Malcolm and Gerti run for him.

dialogues.speaker: POUNDING
dialogues.text: From inside the walls. Something running--  94. Gerti puts pressure on Cole’s wound--

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Jesus...oh jesus...

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: We have to get him help! Malcolm rushes to--

dialogues.speaker: THE FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: Tries to open it. It won’t budge--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: It’s locked! Rushes back to the--

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: As the grandfather clock starts ticking. TICK. TICK. TICK. Gerti and Malcolm turn to it as-- The grandfather clock swings open. A secret door. Out steps a very large man. He’s wearing Malcolm's shirt. A knife in one hand. A cricket bat in the other.

dialogues.speaker: THIS IS BRAHMS
dialogues.text: The real Brahms. A child-like face, despite his age. Tall, taller even than Mr. Heelshire. He has to stoop to get through the passageway and into the living room. He takes two light-as-a-doll steps. His feet wrapped in dirty rags. He’s pale, impossibly - painfully - pale. With sores and scratches covering him. He licks his chapped lips nervously. Looks from face to face. A drop of blood falls from his knife.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Who...? Quiet, almost to himself--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Brahms. In a child-like, high, soft voice--  95.

dialogues.speaker: BRAHMS
dialogues.text: She’s mine. Malcolm moves slowly. Like you would when faced with a bear. Doesn’t take his eyes off Brahms. In a whisper--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Gerti. Get up. Gerti doesn’t move. Can’t move.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: It can’t be....

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Up. Now. Malcolm grabs her under the arms. Lifts her up roughly--

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: What is that thing!? Who is that?! To Gerti--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Get out the back. Get help. Brahms takes a step toward them. Malcolm steps in between them. Looks back at Gerti--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Now! Gerti snaps out of it. Runs for the kitchen--

dialogues.speaker: AT THE SAME TIME
dialogues.text: Brahms let’s out a HORRIBLE YELL. Charges Malcolm. Malcolm puts up his arms in defense as Brahms slams down on him with the bat. Malcolm falls. Brahms hits him again, with a sickening THUD. Knocking Malcolm out. Brahms stands over Cole. Cole looks up, eyes wild--

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: No... Brahms raises the knife and--

dialogues.speaker: THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Gerti sprints through to the back door. Locked. She tries it again, desperate, scared. It doesn’t budge. Scared tears are falling from Gerti’s eyes as she turns around. She knows what’s there--

dialogues.speaker: BRAHMS
dialogues.text: Stands at the other end of the room. The cricket bat in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Please...no... Brahms walks toward Gerti.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Don’t...please... Brahms walks to her and, without stopping, grabs her violently by the hair and drags her out of the kitchen, like a child dragging a doll.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Gerti slides on the floor behind Brahms, SCREAMING in pain and terror. Past Cole, the knife plunged into his chest. And now it’s obvious where Brahms is headed - back into the walls. Gerti struggles, tries to get away when--

dialogues.speaker: SLAM
dialogues.text: Malcolm, hiding behind the couch, slams a piece of the doll’s shattered porcelain head into Brahms’ leg. Brahms lets go of Gerti, falls down to a knee and lets out a SCREAM of agony and anger-- Malcolm staggers to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Upstairs! Gerti helps Malcolm stumble up the stairs while Brahms watches them race from the room. Brahms walks to Cole. Calmly pulls the knife out of his chest. And, with the bat, walks back into the grandfather clock passageway, closing it behind him. Leaving the room empty, quiet...  97. INT. GERTI’S BEDROOM Gerti and Malcolm burst in the room. Gerti slides her dresser in front of the door.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: The phone! Gerti looks for her phone. Finds it, smashed into pieces. Gerti goes to say something when-- CREAKING in the walls. Malcolm and Gerti freeze. Another CREAK. Malcolm and Gerti follow it with their eyes as Brahms moves inside the walls.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: (whispering) Can he get in? Gerti’s mind races - something clicks--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: The closet! Gerti races to the closet--

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: Brahms is crawling through a small hatch-door in the back of the closet. Gerti SLAMS the closet door closed. Gerti and Malcolm brace the door with their bodies as--

dialogues.speaker: WHAM
dialogues.text: Brahms slams into the door from the other side. WHAM! Again. And again! WHAM! But this time Brahms fist goes right through the door. His hand grasps wildly at the air until he gets hold of Gerti’s shirt. Gerti SCREAMS! Flails against the arm. Tries to pull away, but he’s too strong. Pulls her closer and closer to the door. Malcolm looks down. A BELT. He grabs it. Quickly loops it around Brahms hand and PULLS as hard as he can. Brahms’ hand bends in a gruesome direction right into the jagged edge of the splintered door. Brahms lets out a SCREAM OF ANGER. Tries to pull his hand back through the hole. Too late. Malcolm is already looping the other end of the belt around the bedpost.  98.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Hold it! Gerti grabs the belt. Pulls. Malcolm ties the belt off on the bed post. Brahms is trapped, his hand caught outside the door and tied to the bed. He pulls wildly, lifting the bed off the floor, but he can’t get free--

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Gerti and Malcolm flee to the hallway. Malcolm heads for the stairs, but Gerti stops him--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: This way! Gerti races into-- BRAHMS’ ROOM We can still hear Brahms YELLING and RAGING in the other room. Gerti tips over the bookcase. Then runs to the closet and rips everything out--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: There has to be a door here somewhere. This is where it started. She goes to the dresser and tries to pull it away from the wall. It doesn’t budge--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: This is it. We have to pry it open. Malcolm doesn’t move--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: You're not going in there?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: It's the only way. The windows. The doors. Everything is blocked off. But he got out. We have to go in the walls. Malcolm hesitates. A LOUD CRASH in the other room.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: He’s coming. Hurry.  99. Malcolm grabs hold of the dresser and, along with Gerti, pulls. CRACK! The dresser swings open, revealing a passage into the walls. A small bolt lock falls to the floor at Gerti’s feet. Gerti and Malcolm look at each other. Are we really going to do this? Gerti gets down on her hands and knees and pokes her head into the passage. Dark and narrow. The floor is covered with some kind of stained, worn padding. A few pin- pricks of light show down the passageway through holes in the wall. Not the kind of place you would ever choose to enter. Gerti backs out of the passage way, looks at Malcolm.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Ready?

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: No. Gerti takes a breath and crawls into the wall, trailed by Malcolm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black. Gerti reaches out, her hands stretched out in front of her, groping in the darkness, feeling her way along the walls, stepping silently on the padding beneath her feet.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Malcolm?

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Right here... He puts his hand on her shoulder. Gerti’s eyes begin to adjust and we can make out some of the details of the surroundings. The walls are covered in drawings. Faces. Words. The sketches of a madman. Trinkets hanging - necklaces, ties, bits of clothing and decorations. Things Brahms has stolen over the years-- Gerti comes to a pin-prick of light and puts her eye up to it. GERTI’S POV:  100. Looking into her room at the bed and closet. The closet door is open, the belt still tied to the bed. But Brahms is nowhere to be seen when--

dialogues.speaker: BRAHMS
dialogues.text: Walks right past our view.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Ducks down. Stifles a scream.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: What? What is it? Gerti puts her finger to her lips - shhhh. The two of them sit there, in the narrow passageway, waiting, listening.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I don’t hear any--

dialogues.speaker: WHAM
dialogues.text: The blade of Brahms’ knife slams through the wall, stopping just short of Malcolm’s mouth. SCREAMS!

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Run! In a flash, they’re back on their feet, stumbling through the passage, the pictures, the scribblings, the madman- decorations blurring by our view as they race through the walls until they come to--

dialogues.speaker: A FORK IN THE PATH
dialogues.text: Splitting in two different directions. A CREAK somewhere outside of the wall. Gerti’s mind races - trying to figure out where they are in the house...

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Which way?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I don’t know... More CREAKING. The unmistakable sound of steps coming from the right. The decision is made for her. Gerti heads left--  101.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: This way.

dialogues.speaker: END OF THE HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Gerti stops. Nothing but black down the hall. A dead end.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: We have to go back... But Gerti doesn’t move. She’s still looking at the wall. There’s something about it that’s not quite right and then we see--

dialogues.speaker: IT MOVES
dialogues.text: Swaying gently, just a tiny bit. Gerti moves toward it--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: We have to go. Now. Gerti reaches up and touches the wall. It gives to her touch. A THICK BLACK CURTAIN.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: A curtain. She pushes it aside. Another black curtain behind it. And then another one behind that. Gerti pushes her way through them - layer after layer-- She pushes through a final curtain and walks into-- BRAHMS’ ROOM Everything you could need. A sink. A shower. A toilet. A microwave and a fridge. Canned foods. Various tupperware, mostly empty. It's lit dimly with Christmas lights illuminating various stacks of porn magazines and a few porn pictures hung from the walls along with various pages from a coloring book. Toys line the shelves. It’s part jail cell, part demented dorm room.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Jesus...  102. Malcolm and Gerti spread out, investigating the room.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Brahms. He’s been living here. In this room. For 30 years. Malcolm reaches up and touches the walls - they’re covered in some kind of textured foam.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Sound proofed. Everything he could need in here. But Gerti isn’t listening. She’s found a letter - THE SAME LETTER MRS. HEELSHIRE MAILED EARLIER. She reads--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: We won’t be back. We’ve gone on now to heaven where someday we’ll all be reunited. The girl is yours now. A final gift from us. Treat her well. Let her see the beautiful, sweet little boy that we love so very, very much... Gerti lowers the letter. A dazed look on her face as she notices

dialogues.speaker: A BED
dialogues.text: And on it a home-made looking doll, almost life-size. Gerti inches closer, notices the dress it’s wearing. A white dress with wine stains on it. Her dress. It has a necklace - a thin gold chain with a small angel. Her necklace. Gerti reaches out and touches the doll’s sparse, matted hair, clumsily plastered to the doll’s head. As soon as she touches it her hand recoils. It’s real hair - her hair. Gerti’s hand goes up to her own hair. Malcolm steps beside Gerti. He’s gathered supplies. A flashlight. Two kitchen knives. Gerti can’t take her eyes off the doll.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: It’s me. Malcolm holds a knife out to Gerti.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I think I found the way downstairs. Gerti doesn’t move. She just keeps staring at that doll.  103.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Gerti? Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: We can’t stay here any longer. Without taking her eyes off the doll. Shock setting in--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: It’s me. That’s my necklace. My dress. My hair. He’s been watching me. This whole time. Just sitting in the walls watching me. He was here. And they planned the whole thing. They knew what would happen. A beat. Then, finally, Malcolm reaches out and takes the necklace off the doll. He puts it in Gerti’s hand, squeezing her fist around it.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: We have to keep going. A CORNER OF BRAHMS’ ROOM - MOMENTS LATER Malcolm lifts up a hatch in the floor. Gerti and Malcolm peer down it as Malcolm lights the way with the flash light. A ladder leads down to the first floor. Malcolm takes a pen and draws a rectangle on the floor. He puts an X on a back corner.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: We’re here. In the back of the house. Any idea where we might get out.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Think. There has to be something you saw. If we’re just down there walking blindly we’re not going to make it. Gerti puts her finger down on the rectangle Malcolm has drawn. She traces the outside of it, thinking, and as she does we see:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerti’s POV. Murky, foggy. A memory. We pick up a rat- trap. It’s empty. We walk along, fast forward, looking at the wall of the house. Another rat trap. Nothing stands out. We turn the corner of the house. Everything slows down. Directly in front of us is the chimney, surrounded by hedges. BACK IN BRAHMS’ ROOM Gerti’s finger is stopped on the opposite side of the rectangle - almost as far as you can possibly get from their present location.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: The chimney.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: You're sure? Gerti nods.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Couldn't be in the kitchen, could it? Malcolm holds a knife out to Gerti. She doesn’t take it.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: If he catches us he won’t hesitate to kill me. And you... Malcolm looks over at the life-size doll on Brahms’ bed.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: He’1ll do worse to you. Gerti reaches out a timid hand and takes the knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm drops down from the ladder. He covers the flashlight with his shirt, softening its light. He shines it up and down the passageway.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: (whispering) It’s clear. Gerti drops down. This floor is the same as the top. Dark passageways pin-pricked with light shining from the rooms.  105. Gerti peers through one of the pin-pricks at

dialogues.speaker: THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Empty. Silent. We’re peering at it from just underneath a cupboard.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: (whispering) Gerti... He takes her hand in his, leading her down the dark passageway. Gerti follows, lit only by the small slivers of light as they take slow, careful steps.

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND THEM
dialogues.text: The slivers of light disappear. Someone walking by outside the room. Following them. And then THE LIGHTS GO OUT. DARKNESS. Gerti and Malcolm freeze. Gerti drops the knife and raises a shaking hand to her mouth, stifling a scream that comes out as a WHIMPER...

dialogues.speaker: A CREAKING SOUND
dialogues.text: Footsteps. It’s impossible to tell where they’re coming from. The SOUND OF SOMETHING FALLING with a CRASH. And then, in a soft, almost childlike voice calling for Gerti like you might for some pet--

dialogues.speaker: BRAHMS
dialogues.text: Gerti...Gerti...come here pretty Gerti... Gerti and Malcolm crouch down on the floor--

dialogues.speaker: BRAHMS
dialogues.text: You’ve been naughty. More FOOTSTEPS, roaming the house--

dialogues.speaker: BRAHMS
dialogues.text: Come back pretty Gerti, come back...I won’t hurt you... A beat. More FOOTSTEPS - it almost sounds like they are moving away now. Malcolm motions to Gerti - let’s go. They tip-toe down the passageway, as slow and as quiet as they can when--  106. Malcolm brushes against something. A small bell hung on the inside of the wall. One of the hundreds of little trinkets Brahms has decorated his space with-- A SLIGHT TINK. Not much. But enough. Gerti and Malcolm look at each other. HARD FAST STEPS POUND towards them from inside the house-

dialogues.speaker: RUN
dialogues.text: Before Gerti and Malcolm can even take a step--

dialogues.speaker: BRAHMS
dialogues.text: SLAMS through the wall just behind them. He doesn’t make it all the way through, but enough to GRAB GERTI by the hair. She SCREAMS-- Malcolm leaps on Brahms in flash. Stabs him in the shoulder, the blade sinking deep. Brahms SCREAMS, lets go of Gerti. But before Malcolm can pull away, Brahms grabs his knife hand and BITES down like some crazed animal. Malcolm jerks his hand away. He and Gerti turn to run as Brahms struggles his way through the wall, pulling himself with all his might through the splintered dry wall--

dialogues.speaker: PASSAGEWAY
dialogues.text: Gerti and Malcolm, stumbling through the darkness as fast as they can. They turn a corner--

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER PASSAGEWAY
dialogues.text: Pitch black--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: It has to be somewhere here. SCREAMS OF RAGE behind them. Malcolm pulls out the flashlight, shines it down the passageway. Something SHIMMERS. Something metallic. They rush towards it--

dialogues.speaker: A SMALL DOOR
dialogues.text: With two dead-bolts.  107.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Hurry. Gerti fumbles at them, panicked. Malcolm points the flashlight back down the hallway. Empty, but we can hear

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Undoes the first lock. The second. She turns the knob, pushes and...It’s still locked.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: It won’t open! Malcolm shines the flashlight on the door. ANOTHER DEADBOLT at the bottom of the door. Gerti unlocks it, opens the door as--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Turns the flashlight back down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: BRAHMS
dialogues.text: Stands there. Not more than a few feet away. He smiles -— showing a row of yellow, rotten teeth-- No one moves. Gerti stands there with the door open, the moonlight spilling in. Malcolm holds his ground, the flashlight aimed at Brahms face, Brahms squinting back--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: (quietly) Gerti. Run.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Malcolm?

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Run! Gerti darts out the door-- Brahms CHARGES, SCREAMING. Malcolm runs toward him. The two COLLIDE and Malcolm falls back. The two wrestle on the floor. And then, just as quickly it’s over.  108. Brahms stands up, knife in hand. Malcolm lays on the floor gasping. His shirt beginning to stain with blood...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerti sprints through the yard and then slides to a stop in the overgrown shrubbery at the edge of the yard. She hides on her stomach - looking back at--

dialogues.speaker: THE PASSAGEWAY DOOR
dialogues.text: Brahms emerges. He calls for Gerti, his voice unnaturally boyish again. A lost little boy calling for his mother--

dialogues.speaker: BRAHMS
dialogues.text: Gerti? Gerti? Come back. Please come back. I’m sorry. I’m sorry, Gerti... Brahms scans the yard then disappears back in the house. Gerti starts to get up when Brahms reappears. He drags Malcolm to the doorway, holding him there as he speaks--

dialogues.speaker: BRAHMS
dialogues.text: He’s hurt. He needs your help... A beat. Suddenly shifting to a man’s angry voice--

dialogues.speaker: BRAHMS
dialogues.text: If you leave I'll kill him! I’11 kill him just like the other one! Brahms surveys the yard. Back to a childish voice--

dialogues.speaker: BRAHMS
dialogues.text: GERTI! GET BACK HERE! DON’T LEAVE ME!

dialogues.speaker: I'LL BE GOOD
dialogues.text: Gerti, on her belly, backs up, deeper into the edge of the yard. She turns and crawls, faster and faster away from the house--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerti emerges from the bushes to the main road. Long black pavement as far as the eye can see. No cars. Not even the hope of a car coming by.  109. She looks back at the house. Dark. Silent. No sign of the carnage inside. She begins to walk, down that long black road - away from the house. Away from Malcolm. She slows. Stops.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: No. She turns.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: No. And starts to walk back to the house. As if convincing herself--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I’m not running away. I’m not leaving him... Gerti walks faster. Her bare feet padding quickly across the cold, moonlit pavement. Then faster, breaking into a run back to the house-- EXT. MALCOLM’S TRUCK - NIGHT Still parked in the driveway. All the tires are flat, stabbed with a knife. Brahms wasn’t taking any chances. Gerti opens up the back of the truck. She searches for something. Finds it. A long screwdriver. She places it into the back of her pants and walks to--

dialogues.speaker: THE FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: A thick wood beam placed on the hooks on the front of the door. Gerti lifts the beam off. Opens the door and steps inside--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerti takes a step inside. Dark. The remnants of the violence and chaos that just took place. An overturned chair. The railing on the stairs is splintered. Gerti keeps walking, her feet padding softly in the silent house--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerti walks inside. Stops. Cole’s corpse lays just to the right of her. She sucks in a breath. Every atom in her body tells her to scream. To run. She keeps going to--

dialogues.speaker: THE RECORD PLAYER
dialogues.text: And puts on a record. At the same time something MOVES IN THE WALLS. Gerti pauses - but only for an instant - then puts the needle down.

dialogues.speaker: THE MUSIC ROARS TO LIFE
dialogues.text: Gerti sits down on the couch and waits. It doesn’t take long. Brahms emerges silently from somewhere in the shadows. A hulking figure. He stands there in front of Gerti, his chest heaving. The bloody knife shaking in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: I didn’t leave you, Brahms. I promised you I wouldn’t. Brahms doesn’t say anything. Just stands there staring at her, his eyes as lifeless as a doll’s.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: It’s time for bed. Gerti gets up, calmly takes a few steps toward the entranceway. Stops. She looks back at Brahms. Ina

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Brahms. It’s time for bed. Now. A beat. Brahms’ hand tightens around the knife. He walks toward Gerti, one heavy step after the next, his eyes fixed on her. He walks right up to her, only inches away-- Gerti keeps her eyes fixed on his, looking straight up at him. One swipe with the knife, that’s all it would take-- Brahms’ hand tightens around the knife again and then... he drops it. He walks past Gerti, heading for the stairs. Gerti lets him pass, then follows. As she does she reaches back with her hand, feels the screwdriver stuck in the back of her pants...  111. BRAHMS’ ROOM - CONTINUOUS Brahms stops at the side of his bed, his back turned to Gerti, a pouting child.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Get in bed. Brahms sits down. The little bed sagging under his weight.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Under the covers. Gerti’s voice cracks - showing a glimpse of the fear she’s hiding. Brahms looks up at her--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: (loud, firm) Under the covers. Brahms pulls the covers up. Climbs under them. Gerti leans down, tucking the blankets around him.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: You don’t get a story tonight. That’s your punishment. Gerti stands up, Brahms looking up at her - almost looking boyish for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: BRAHMS
dialogues.text: (little boy voice) Kiss. Gerti goes cold inside. She doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: BRAHMS
dialogues.text: (little boy voice) Kiss. Gerti force a smile on her lips.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Of course... She leans in towards Brahms, at the same time she reaches back for the screwdriver, grabs it in hand. Gerti’s lips are almost to Brahms forehead when-- He grabs her HARD by her head and neck, forces her down to his lips and kisses her. Forcing his tongue in her mouth, pulling her down on the bed--  112. Gerti pulls the screwdriver from her pants. SLAMS it into Brahms’ belly-- Brahms SCREAMS. Releases Gerti. She falls back against the wall. Brahms leaps to his feet, the sheets stuck to him where Gerti stabbed him with the screwdriver.

dialogues.speaker: HE CHARGES GERTI
dialogues.text: She manages to get to her feet right as BRAHMS GRABS HER BY THE NECK with both his huge hands.

dialogues.speaker: BRAHMS SQUEEZES
dialogues.text: Lifts Gerti off of her feet. Gerti chokes. Tears at Brahms’ hands. But he’s too strong. Her hands search Brahms’ body, looking for--

dialogues.speaker: THE SCREWDRIVER
dialogues.text: She pulls it out of him. SLAMS it back into his belly. BRAHMS SCREAMS but doesn’t let go. Gerti stabs him again. Brahms still doesn’t let go. Gerti is fading. Her eyes fluttering, her arm weakening. It’s a battle of wills now-- Gerti slams the screwdriver into his side. Brahms drops to his knees, taking Gerti down with him. She gasps, taking in a breath. She stabs him again. His grip loosens. She has the upper hand now as she slams it right into his sternum. BLOOD comes out of Brahms mouth. Gerti twists the screwdriver. Brahms SCREAMS IN AGONY finally releases Gerti and falls back on the floor, the screwdriver stuck in his chest, rising and falling with his breathing-- Gerti gasps for air, the color returning to her face. Then forces herself to her feet and scrambles out of the room-—

dialogues.speaker: BRAHMS
dialogues.text: Mummy...mummy...  113.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Gerti sprints through, towards the Grandfather clock. Pries it open--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Malcolm!? Malcolm!? She moves quickly--

dialogues.speaker: INTO THE WALLS
dialogues.text: And through the darkness. The flicker of a flash light glows somewhere ahead-

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Malcolm? In a voice that’s weak, but alive--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Gerti. Gerti turns a corner in the walls. Sees Malcolm. Bloody but still breathing. Holding the flashlight. Gerti takes him in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Malcolm...

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: You came back. Gerti smiles at him--

dialogues.speaker: GERTI
dialogues.text: Yeah. I came back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerti helps Malcolm to the pick-up truck. Malcolm looks at the tires as he pulls out his keys--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Just bought those tires. He hands the keys to Gerti smiling. Then coughs - a violent, sick sounding cough. Gerti helps him into the truck--  114. INT. MALCOLM’S TRUCK - NIGHT Gerti turns on the ignition. Let’s out a sigh - thank god it works. She puts it in reverse. Turns to look behind her when--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: (terrified) Gerti! Gerti turns back around just in time to see--

dialogues.speaker: BRAHMS
dialogues.text: Leap onto the hood of the car. He has the screwdriver in his hand, slams it into the windshield, shattering it. Gerti doesn’t blink-- Gerti looks right into his eyes, shifts the car into drive and SLAMS ON THE GAS-- The truck Speeds forward, directly towards the front door of the house--

dialogues.speaker: BRAHMS
dialogues.text: Turns around, just in time to see

dialogues.speaker: CRASH
dialogues.text: The truck SLAMS through the front of the house. Brahms slams into the stair case - falling on the splintered railing - a piece of wood going right through his chest. Gerti puts the truck in reverse, pulling out through the debris. Then slams the truck into drive again, right at Brahms--—

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Gerti...? She slams on the gas.

dialogues.speaker: WHAM
dialogues.text: Nails Brahms, crushing him between the car and house. This time he won’t be getting back up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. MALCOLM’S TRUCK - DAWN The truck bumps along violently, the horrible sounds of metal on pavement. They’re traveling some deserted country road, getting further and further away from the nightmare they just experienced... Malcolm slides down, putting his head on Gerti’s lap as she drives. She puts an arm over him, protecting him-- Gerti looks at him, smiles - a real honest to goodness smile despite everything that’s happened--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tires are gone. They’re down to the metal wheels. The truck rumbles along, sparks in its wake where the rims meet the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: WE PULL OUT
dialogues.text: Further and further leaving the truck behind, focusing instead on the sun rising above the impossibly green pastures and the morning fog lifting from the land... .--and then even further out, until the world looks peaceful and still and it’s impossible to tell if we're looking at the real world anymore or some too-perfect painting of the English countryside...
